singapore_query_001.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are a group of 3 food bloggers visiting Singapore for 5 days. They are interested in maritime history and waterfront attractions, educational experiences and guided tours, street food, hawker centers, and cooking experiences. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_001.answer:
Day 1: Arrival in Singapore
- Check-in at the hotel
- Explore the Civic District and visit key historical landmarks such as St Andrew's Cathedral, National Gallery Singapore, and the Asian Civilisations Museum
- Have a light lunch at a local restaurant in the Civic District

Day 2: Exploring the Colonial District
- Visit Fort Canning Park and explore its gardens, lawns, and historical artefacts
- Take a guided tour of the Colonial District and learn about Singapore's British colonial history
- Have a light lunch at a local restaurant in the Colonial District

Day 3: Exploring the Quays on the Singapore River
- Walk along the river and visit Clarke Quay, Robertson Quay, and Boat Quay
- Explore the waterfront attractions and enjoy the lively nightlife
- Have a light lunch at a local restaurant along the river

Day 4: Exploring the Kampong Glam District
- Visit the Sultan Mosque and explore the many side streets in Kampong Glam
- Have a light lunch at a local restaurant in Kampong Glam

Day 5: Exploring the Jalan Besar District
- Visit the Istana and explore the grounds
- Have a light lunch at a local restaurant in Jalan Besar

Day 6: Lighter Day for Recovery
- Visit the Singapore Zoo and enjoy the animal exhibits
- Have a light lunch at a local restaurant in the Zoo

Day 7: Departure from Singapore
- Check-out of the hotel and depart for home

ACTIVITIES TO
EXPLORE IN SINGAPORE

BOX BACKPACKERS HOSTEL

1 VESPA TOURS BY BETEL
& TOURS AND SIDEWAYS,SG

LET’S GO! NATIONAL
BIKE SINGAPORE PARKS BOARD

® letsgobikesingapore.com

CHINATOWN TRISHAW EXPEDITION
WALKING TOURS BY TRISHAW UNCLE

KAMPONG
GLAM

Some say Kampong Glam really is glam
(a local term meaning ‘glamorous’). The area has
an eclectic blend of history, culture and a super-
trendy lifestyle scene. Start from the landmark Sultan
Mosque, and wander through the many side streets.
The grounds of the former ‘Istana’ (‘palace’) to Sultan
Hussain Mohammed Shah is home to the Malay

103 - A QUICK GUIDE TO SINGAPORE’S DISTRICTS /

history and culture better. Wander the streets and you'll
soon uncover Haji Lane, a row of multi-label stores,
quirky boutiques as well as hip bars and cafes. Or pick
up traditional wares such as Persian carpets, kebaya
dresses and handmade perfumes from Arab Street and
Bussorah Street. The nasi padang (Indonesian dishes
flavoured with spices and served with rice) at Hjh
Maimunah is famous among locals. Café and boutique
Maison Ikkoku on Kandahar Street offers tasty
modern grub, and also houses an excellent rooftop

Heritage Centre, where you can get to know Malay cocktail bar.

JALAN BESAR,
ROCHER,
LAVENDER

Now a conserved area, Jalan Besar is home
to an eclectic range of eateries, cafés, entertainment
venues, and religious sites. It's also a hostel hotspot,
and backpackers constantly flock here. Beyond the
neon lights of bars and lounges, Jalan Besar is rife with
hip cafés that are now calling the neighbourhood's
many shophouses home. You can easily spend an
entire afternoon hopping from one spot to another
such as Chye Seng Huat Hardware, all while tucking
into hearty brunch plates, classic French pastries and
modern takes on local cuisine such as Non Entrée
Desserts. The district is also making a name for itself
as a haven for Third Wave coffee, so you will have
plenty of fuel for your trip.

THE CIVIC
DISTRICT

The Civic District is where Singapore's
historical, architectural and cultural heritage started.
Located right at the mouth of the Singapore River, the
Civic District is at the heart of the city's past, with key
landmarks from prominent historical figures such as Sir
Stamford Raffles, the man who founded Singapore, to
up-and-coming architectural icons of the 21st century.
Among key historical landmarks include St Andrew's
Cathedral, National Gallery Singapore which comprises
the historical Supreme Court and City Hall, Padang,
the Asian Civilisations Museum, The Arts House (Old
Parliament House) and Victoria Theatre, overlooking the
magnificent Fullerton Hotel and Esplanade - Theatres
on the Bay which locals affectionately call "the durian”.

BRAS BASAH BUGIS

Bras Basah.Bugis Precinct is where to go for a slice of Singapore's rich heritage, preserved

architecture and palpable energy. Head here for fine museums, national monuments and other

institutions, such as art schools and the Central Public Library. One of Singapore's oldest districts,
Bras Basah derived its name from the Malay term for ‘wet rice’ and Sir Stamford Raffles picked the area to be
the European center of Singapore Town. The adjacent Bugis Street, named after the seafaring Bugis people
from Indonesia who came here to trade with local merchants, has a less pristine past. You could spend days
just soaking in the vibe of this buzzing district. The district is home to museums such as the National Museum
of Singapore, The Singapore Art Museum and Peranakan Museum, and national monuments like the Armenian
Church and Central Fire Station, Singapore's oldest fire station. Explore CHIJMES, an enclave of restaurants and
bars in the middle of the city. The former chapel and school with its green lawns, marble waterfalls, courtyards
and neoclassical buildings — harks back to a bygone, more gracious age. A thriving district with a colourful past,
it now boasts everything shoppers could ever ask for; malls such as Bugis+ and Bugis Junction, charming
boutiques, bustling street markets, and of course, bargains at every corner.

THE COLONIAL
DISTRICT

Singapore's Colonial District is peppered with
reminders of British colonial rule. Together with Bras Basah
Bugis district and adjoining into the Civic District, it's the
centerpiece of Singapore surrounded by more modern
trappings that rise up around it. The district is anchored
by Fort Canning Park, an iconic hilltop landmark that has
witnessed many of Singapore's historical milestones. The
hill once sited the palaces of 14th century Malay Kings and
served as the Headquarters of the Far East Command Centre and British Army Barracks. Today, Fort Canning Park
is a venue for celebrations. Its expansive, sprawling lawns play host to concerts, theatre productions and festivals
such as Shakespeare in the Park, Ballet Under the Stars, and Films at the Fort, while weddings, parties and
gatherings are a regular sight in the park's venue spaces. Its ancient artefacts are a must-see for history buffs, and
its lush greenery and expansive lawns offer a variety of arts, heritage and nature experiences. Down the hill, you
can trace Singapore's history through stamps at the Singapore Philatelic Museum before stopping for lunch at the
Raffles Hotel. Raffles Hotel was the crown of colonial indulgence with a reputation of luxury. It is at this hotel's bar
where the legendary Singapore Sling was created

} THE QUAYS
ON SINGAPORE
RIVER

Consisting of a trio of Clarke Quay,
Robertson Quay and Boat Quay, you can literally
walk from the mouth of Singapore River through the
river valleys along some of the most pristine walking
paths. Shophouses along Boat Quay that used to
be the centre of trade has now been conserved and
adapted for modern use, offering up various bars,
‘ pubs and restaurants. Warehouses along Clarke
Quay are today Iconic dance clubs and live music
venues, rooftop bars, creating trendy nightspots for heart-pumping entertainment. Together, both Clarke Quay and
Boat Quay is a must-have stop for the city's most lively nightlife spots. As you move further inwards, Robertson Quay
offers a more quiet respite, with locals often seen running along its banks. The area combines upperclass residential
apartments with designer hotels such as M Social and The Warehouse Hotel with wonderful choices of gastronomic
options that would satisfy any foodie.

KAMPONG
GLAM

Some say Kampong Glam really is glam
(a local term meaning ‘glamorous’. The area has
an eclectic blend of history, culture and a super-
trendy lifestyle scene. Start from the landmark Sultan
Mosque, and wander through the many side streets.
The grounds of the former ‘Istana’ (‘palace’) to Sultan
Hussain Mohammed Shah is home to the Malay

singapore_query_002.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 6 business colleagues visiting Singapore for 4 days. They are interested in colonial architecture and historical landmarks, ethnic neighborhoods like Chinatown and Little India. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_002.answer:
Day 1: 
- Start the day with a visit to the Singapore Botanic Gardens, which is the city's first and only UNESCO World Heritage Site and a beautiful garden to explore.
- After lunch, head to Fort Canning Park, which is a popular spot for panoramic views of the city and a great place to relax.
- In the afternoon, take a stroll through Chinatown, where you can experience the vibrant culture and history of Singapore's Chinese community.
- For dinner, try some local cuisine at a Chinatown restaurant or a food court.

Day 2: 
- Start the day with a visit to Little India, where you can explore the colorful streets and learn about Singapore's diverse ethnic communities.
- After lunch, take a guided tour of the Singapore River, which offers stunning views of the city and a chance to learn about Singapore's colonial history.
- In the afternoon, take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along the Singapore River.
- For dinner, try some local cuisine at a Little India restaurant or a food court.

Day 3: 
- Start the day with a visit to the Singapore River, which offers stunning views of the city and a chance to learn about Singapore's colonial history.
- After lunch, take a guided tour of the Singapore River, which offers stunning views of the city and a chance to learn about Singapore's colonial history.
- In the afternoon, take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along the Singapore River.
- For dinner, try some local cuisine at a Little India restaurant or a food court.

Day 4: 
- Start the day with a visit to the Singapore Botanic Gardens, which is the city's first and only UNESCO World Heritage Site and a beautiful garden to explore.
- After lunch, take a guided tour of the Singapore Botanic Gardens, which offers stunning views of the city and a chance to learn about Singapore's colonial history.
- In the afternoon, take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along the Singapore River.
- For dinner, try some local cuisine at a Little India restaurant or a food court.

Lighter Day: 
- Start the day with a visit to the Singapore River, which offers stunning views of the city and a chance to learn about Singapore's colonial history.
- After lunch, take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along the Singapore River.
- In the afternoon, take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along the Singapore River.
- For dinner, try some local cuisine at a Little India restaurant or a food court.

CHINATOWN
WALKING TOURS

Operated by The Chinatown Association, there's a
walking tour organised on every day of the week
that let you immerse yourself with the underbelly
of Chinatown. Move your senses with the sights
and sounds of hawkers cooking, coffee brewing
and locals bargain-hunting even as you taste
authentic traditional favourites such as Kopi-O,
water cakes and rice rolls in the "Good Morning,
Ni Hao" walking tour!

Explore the traditional customs that surround the
life of the early Chinese immigrant and discover
the reasons behind each practice in the "Passage
of Life: Birth, Marriage & Death” walking tour.

Visit Chinatown at sundown in the Nightout @
Chinatown Walking Tour, where the streets come
alive! Savour authentic Chinese food and test
your bargaining skills at the Street Market. Take a
leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop
onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.

® chinatown.sg

TRISHAW EXPEDITION
BY TRISHAW UNCLE

Say hello to uncle! Trishaw Uncle pays tribute to all
trishaw riders, for providing transport services rain or
shine, from the time before cars, buses and trains.

Embark on a trishaw expedition that takes you through
the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. Expect

a range of sights such as the Rex Cinema and Sri
Veeramakaliamman Temple and learn more about the
various roads such as Selegie Road and Serangoon
Road. Tours are available for Little India, Kampong
Glam, Chinatown as well the Singapore River.

® trishawuncle.com.sg

1/02 - CONTENTS & A QUICK GUIDE TO SINGAPORE'S DISTRICTS /

A QUICK GUIDE

ORCHARD

Don't just sightsee, be an explorer. Orchard

Road, Asia's most famous shopping street, is

home to fashion favourites, specialist stores
and loads of other lifestyle choices. Today, Orchard
Road is flanked by iconic shopping malls, restaurants
and hotels, choc-a-bloc with retail, dining and enter-
tainment choice for every taste and budget.
The Singapore Visitor Centre is located on Orchard
Road just opposite Orchard Gateway. Discover more
places to explore and get help with ticketing and
reservations. Next to the centre is Emerald Hill Road,

lined with bars and clubs to wind down after a long day

of exploration. The east end of Orchard Road leads to
the Bras Basah and Fort Canning Park while the west
end of the street is just a stone's throw away from the
Singapore Botanic Gardens, the city's first and only

UNESCO World Heritage Site and a beautiful garden to

stop by.

Remember to make a detour to Dempsey Hill, one

of Singapore's most hip and quaint neighbourhoods,
nestled away in lush greenery just minutes from
Orchard Road. Here you'll be spoilt for choice for

the night's meal with options that include Michelin-
starred Candlenut, Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar, The
Disgruntled Chef. Or go green and experience Open
Farm Community's refreshing farm-to-table concept.

TIONG BAHRU

Tiong Bahru is the oldest housing estate

in Singapore, and when you visit this.

quaint community, you'll immediately
notice an intriguing mix of old and new. While many
older residents have lived in the shophouses and flats
here for decades, the younger generation flock here
for the food, shops, and culture. And as food goes,
the choices are abundant. From the sprawling Tiong
Bahru Market with its famous chwee kueh to the
hip Tiong Bahru Bakery, there are plenty of options
for a good meal in the morning. Fancy a coffee
and a quick bite? There are lots of cafés to choose
from — Forty Hands, Flock and cupcakes specialists
Plain Vanilla are just a few of them. It's a great place
to go for a spot of retail therapy, too. Independent
bookstore BooksActually stocks plenty of local
titles and retro knick-knacks, while Curated Records
offers a selection of vinyls, from rare vintage LPs to
mainstream hits.

LITTLE INDIA

Singapore's most colourful district, Little

India's bustling streets are a magnet for

explorers. From rows of shops exuding the
aroma of spices, to fortune-telling tables sprawled
along walkways, the precinct has stood as a cultural
vanguard of Singapore. Tucked away in its roads, you'll
find numerous landmarks of the city's many ethnic
and religious groups including the visually stunning
Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple, Kampong Kapor
Methodist Church, and the colourful expressions of
heritage at the House of Tan Teng Niah. Explore Little
India's heritage trail along its streets and back alleys,
and your eyes will be drawn to extravagant murals
showcasing Singapore's colourful past.

When you're done soaking in the sights and sounds,
to Tekka Centre and experience the bustling hawker
and “wet market” on its ground level with a battalion of
rainbow-coloured textile and tailor shops up above.

singapore_query_003.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 5 nature and wildlife enthusiasts visiting Singapore for 4 days. They are interested in luxury experiences and fine dining, religious sites and spiritual experiences. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_003.answer:
Day 1: Arrive in Singapore and check into your hotel. Take a guided tour of Singapore's historical landmarks, such as Fort Canning Park and the Merlion Park, to learn about Singapore's rich history and culture. Enjoy a luxurious dinner at a fine dining restaurant in the city center.

Day 2: Visit the Singapore Botanic Gardens and take a guided tour of the gardens. Enjoy a luxurious lunch at a high-end restaurant in the city center.

Day 3: Take a guided tour of the Singapore Zoo and enjoy a luxurious dinner at a fine dining restaurant in the city center.

Day 4: Visit the Singapore River and take a guided tour of the Singapore River. Enjoy a luxurious dinner at a high-end restaurant in the city center.

Lighter Day: Take a guided tour of the Singapore Botanic Gardens and enjoy a luxurious lunch at a high-end restaurant in the city center.

contexts.text:
1/10 - SCENIC TRAILS TO RUN OR HIKE IN SINGAPORE /

SCENIC TR

MacRitchie Reservoir Park
Panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of

walking at 25 metres above ground are all part of the
experience when you traverse the TreeTop Walk, a
250-metre-long freestanding suspension bridge. See
first-hand the layers of the rainforest, from the ground
all the way to the canopy and the emergent layer of
trees, when you take on this scenic seven-kilometre-
long roundtrip to the bridge. From the carpark at Venus
Drive, it's a three- to four-hour hike—do note that the
TreeTop Walk only allows access from one direction.

Southern Ridges. Keep your camera on hand when
you hike the photogenic ten-kilometre-long network of
trails known as the Southern Ridges. The route starts
at HarbourFront Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) station and
takes you three to five hours to walk through Mount
Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill and HortPark before
ending at Kent Ridge Park. Soak in the scenic views

of our skyline and the Southern Islands at the peak of
Mount Faber Park, which is also where you can take
photos with the Merlion sculpture—one of seven that
dot the island. For Instagram-worthy pictures, we
definitely recommend Henderson Waves, the highest

pedestrian bridge in Singapore. The post-modern wood

and steel structure's also an ideal venue for a romantic
night stroll, as it's majestically illuminated by glowing
LED lights from 7pm to 7am.

Relive the footsteps of Malay kings and British
governors at Fort Canning Park. This area used to

be home to Malay royalty, and was also where Sir
Stamford Raffles built his first house, which eventually
became the place of residence for governors. Connect
with history when you explore Fort Canning Service
Reservoir to discover landmarks such as the nine-
pound cannon that dates back to the 19th century;
headstones that mark the site of Singapore's first
Christian cemetery; and Fort Gate, a remnant of the
fortress that was built on this hill.

IN SINGAPO

The golden hour washing over the city's CBD is a

sight to behold. Skyscrapers glimmer and Marina

Bay glistens—it all makes for a postcard-perfect
backdrop for your evening run. The area's proximity

to attractions, restaurants and heritage monuments
also means there's plenty to do and see after this

easy 3.9-kilometre route. Start at the Merlion Park
next to One Fullerton and you'll run past The Fullerton
Heritage precinct, across Marina Bay Sands. You can
cut through the underpass that connects the iconic
towers to Gardens by the Bay and whizz pask lakes and
conservatories before entering the Supertree Grove.
End your run with a last dash towards your final stop,
the Marina Barrage where Singapore's skyline lights up
to celebrate the completion of your run goal.

If there's one place in Singapore that's synonymous
with outdoor revelry, it's East Coast Park, where some
seven million locals and tourists flock to for the variety
of sporting, entertainment and dining attractions. Along
this 15-kiliometre stretch of beach, you'll find hordes
of cyclists and roller bladers enjoying the sun and sea
breeze, while cable skiing and water sports are on offer
for those who prefer wetter pursuits.

Sungai Buloh Wetlands Reserve. Enjoy an up-close
look at mud lobsters, tree-climbing crabs and monitor
lizards when you stroll along the 500-metre-long
boardwalk of the mangrove swamps in Sungei Buloh
Wetland Reserve. The boardwalk runs parallel to the
Wetland Centre. Look to the sky when you head to

the Migratory Bird Trail just a short walk away. From
behind the five hides, two platforms and the 18-metre-
tall Aerie Tower featured along the trail, you can

quietly observe migratory birds such as the Common
Redshank and Pacific Golden Plover that shack up in
this reserve from September to March. Kingfishers,
herons and egrets also visit the reserve regularly.

Bukit Timah is an expansive twist of roads and
buildings, but within the district are tranquil spots for
some quiet. Take
a hike up Bukit
Timah Hill or, for
the adventurous,
go off-tangent and
explore the jungles
of Bukit Timah
Nature Reserve by
mountain bike or
foot.

Punggol is a little far off from the city centre, but you'll
be surprised by the options awaiting you on this end
of the island. Explore the Punggol Waterway Park

by bicycle—there are scores of rental shops around
offering hourly rates—or meander the carved paths of
Coney Island.

710 - SCENIC TRAILS TO RUN OR HIKE IN SINGAPORE /

SCENIC TR

MacRitchie Reservoir Park
Panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of

walking at 25 metres above ground are all part of the
experience when you traverse the TreeTop Walk, a
250-metre-long freestanding suspension bridge. See
first-hand the layers of the rainforest, from the ground
all the way to the canopy and the emergent layer of
trees, when you take on this scenic seven-kilometre-
long roundtrip to the bridge. From the carpark at Venus
Drive, it's a three- to four-hour hike—do note that the
TreeTop Walk only allows access from one direction.

Southern Ridges. Keep your camera on hand when
you hike the photogenic ten-kilometre-long network of
trails known as the Southern Ridges. The route starts
at HarbourFront Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) station and
takes you three to five hours to walk through Mount
Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill and HortPark before
ending at Kent Ridge Park. Soak in the scenic views

of our skyline and the Southern Islands at the peak of
Mount Faber Park, which is also where you can take
photos with the Merlion sculpture—one of seven that
dot the island. For Instagram-worthy pictures, we
definitely recommend Henderson Waves, the highest

pedestrian bridge in Singapore. The post-modern wood

and steel structure's also an ideal venue for a romantic
night stroll, as it's majestically illuminated by glowing
LED lights from 7pm to 7am.

Relive the footsteps of Malay kings and British
governors at Fort Canning Park. This area used to

be home to Malay royalty, and was also where Sir
Stamford Raffles built his first house, which eventually
became the place of residence for governors. Connect
with history when you explore Fort Canning Service
Reservoir to discover landmarks such as the nine-
pound cannon that dates back to the 19th century;
headstones that mark the site of Singapore's first
Christian cemetery; and Fort Gate, a remnant of the
fortress that was built on this hill.

IN SINGAPO

The golden hour washing over the city's CBD is a

sight to behold. Skyscrapers glimmer and Marina

Bay glistens—it all makes for a postcard-perfect
backdrop for your evening run. The area's proximity

to attractions, restaurants and heritage monuments
also means there's plenty to do and see after this

easy 3.9-kilometre route. Start at the Merlion Park
next to One Fullerton and you'll run past The Fullerton
Heritage precinct, across Marina Bay Sands. You can
cut through the underpass that connects the iconic
towers to Gardens by the Bay and whizz pask lakes and
conservatories before entering the Supertree Grove.
End your run with a last dash towards your final stop,
the Marina Barrage where Singapore's skyline lights up
to celebrate the completion of your run goal.

If there's one place in Singapore that's synonymous
with outdoor revelry, it's East Coast Park, where some
seven million locals and tourists flock to for the variety
of sporting, entertainment and dining attractions. Along
this 15-kiliometre stretch of beach, you'll find hordes
of cyclists and roller bladers enjoying the sun and sea
breeze, while cable skiing and water sports are on offer
for those who prefer wetter pursuits.

lizards when you stroll along the 500-metre-long

Wetland Centre. Look to the sky when you head to

the Migratory Bird Trail just a short walk away. From
behind the five hides, two platforms and the 18-metre-
tall Aerie Tower featured along the trail, you can

quietly observe migratory birds such as the Common
Redshank and Pacific Golden Plover that shack up in
this reserve from September to March. Kingfishers,
herons and egrets also visit the reserve regularly.

Bukit Timah is an expansive twist of roads and
buildings, but within the district are tranquil spots for
some quiet. Take
a hike up Bukit
Timah Hill or, for
the adventurous,
go off-tangent and
explore the jungles
of Bukit Timah
Nature Reserve by
mountain bike or
foot.

be surprised by the options awaiting you on this end
of the island. Explore the Punggol Waterway Park

by bicycle—there are scores of rental shops around
offering hourly rates—or meander the carved paths of

‘4 @ letsgobikesingapore.com

CHINATOWN
WALKING TOURS

Operated by The Chinatown Association, there's a
walking tour organised on every day of the week
that let you immerse yourself with the underbelly
of Chinatown. Move your senses with the sights
and sounds of hawkers cooking, coffee brewing
and locals bargain-hunting even as you taste
authentic traditional favourites such as Kopi-O,
water cakes and rice rolls in the "Good Morning,
Ni Hao" walking tour!

Explore the traditional customs that surround the
life of the early Chinese immigrant and discover
the reasons behind each practice in the "Passage
of Life: Birth, Marriage & Death” walking tour.

Visit Chinatown at sundown in the Nightout @
Chinatown Walking Tour, where the streets come
alive! Savour authentic Chinese food and test
your bargaining skills at the Street Market. Take a
leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop
onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.

® chinatown.sg

TRISHAW EXPEDITION
BY TRISHAW UNCLE

Say hello to uncle! Trishaw Uncle pays tribute to all
trishaw riders, for providing transport services rain or
shine, from the time before cars, buses and trains.

Embark on a trishaw expedition that takes you through
the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. Expect

a range of sights such as the Rex Cinema and Sri
Veeramakaliamman Temple and learn more about the
various roads such as Selegie Road and Serangoon
Road. Tours are available for Little India, Kampong
Glam, Chinatown as well the Singapore River.

® trishawuncle.com.sg

singapore_query_003.client_description: are 5 nature and wildlife enthusiasts visiting Singapore for 4 days. They are interested in luxury experiences and fine dining, religious sites and spiritual experiences

singapore_query_004.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 6 adventure seekers visiting Singapore for 7 days. They are interested in modern art galleries and contemporary culture, educational experiences and guided tours, luxury experiences and fine dining. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_004.answer:
Day 1: Explore Singapore's modern art galleries and contemporary culture by visiting the National Gallery Singapore and the ArtScience Museum. Enjoy a guided tour of the city's cultural landmarks and learn about Singapore's rich history and diverse communities.

Day 2: Take a guided walking tour of Chinatown to immerse yourself in Singapore's traditional customs and enjoy authentic traditional favorites such as Kopi-O, water cakes, and rice rolls. Visit the "Good Morning, Ni Hao" walking tour and "Passage of Life: Birth, Marriage & Death" walking tour.

Day 3: Embark on a trishaw expedition that takes you through the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. Learn about the various roads such as Selegie Road and Serangoon Road. Tours are available for Little India, Kampong Glam, Chinatown, and the Singapore River.

Day 4: Visit the National Parks Board to explore Singapore's parks and gardens and learn about the various workshops and guided walks they offer. Take a guided tour of the Central Nature Reserve and enjoy local drinks and snacks.

Day 5: Take a guided tour of the Singapore River and enjoy a Bumboat Cruise along the river. Visit the Singapore River and learn about the history and significance of the river.

Day 6: Visit the Singapore River and enjoy a Bumboat Cruise along the river. Visit the Singapore River and learn about the history and significance of the river.

Day 7: Take a guided tour of the Singapore River and enjoy a Bumboat Cruise along the river. Visit the Singapore River and learn about the history and significance of the river.

Lighter Day: On the lighter day, the adventure seekers can enjoy a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River. Enjoy the beautiful scenery and take in the vibrant atmosphere of the river.

singapore_query_004.client_description: are 6 adventure seekers visiting Singapore for 7 days. They are interested in modern art galleries and contemporary culture, educational experiences and guided tours, luxury experiences and fine dining

singapore_query_005.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 7 young adults (ages 23-28) visiting Singapore for 4 days. They are interested in cultural heritage sites and traditional architecture, wellness activities and relaxation, botanical gardens and wildlife conservation. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_005.answer:
Day 1: Explore Fort Canning Park and the Southern Ridges
Day 2: Visit Gardens by the Bay and Gardens by the Bay South Garden
Day 3: Explore Bukit Timah Hill and the Bukit Timah Nature Reserve
Day 4: Relax at the Punggol Waterway Park and enjoy a light lunch
Day 5: Light hike at MacRitchie Reservoir Park and enjoy panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of walking at 25 metres above ground.

/ 08 - LITTLE EXPLORERS: BEING WITH MOTHER NATURE /

MEET
SUBARAJ RAJATHURAI

Many of Singapore's nature reserves exist due
" 4 to the efforts of a few individuals like Subaraj
Rajathurai: Self-taught naturalist and veteran

wildlife consultant. Over the last 35 years, he
GARDENS y
BY TH E BAY campaigned peacefully behind the scenes

to preserve some of Singapore's well-loved
ecosystems. In 1987, he and three others drafted
a proposal to save Sungei Buloh, a mangrove

Gardens by the Bay is a quick getaway to some serious greenery, a 101-ha horticultural park with two
conservatories, the Cloud Forest and the Flower Dome. The cool-moist conservatory that is the Cloud Forest
features a 35m-tall mountain covered in plants such as orchids and also sports the world's tallest indoor
waterfall. Meanwhile, the Flower Dome replicates a cool-dry climate and houses plants from the Mediterranean
region and also a Flower Field, where the displays change regularly.

forest in northwest Singapore which was slated
for redevelopment by the government. Thanks
to their perseverance, the wetland was declared
a nature park six years later. In 1992, Subaraj
was also part of the research team responsible
for saving the 123.8 hectares of forest at Lower
Peirce Reservoir.

While tickets are required for entry into the domes, the large three surrounding gardens are open to public to
enjoy. The highlight within the Bay South Garden is the Children's Garden filled with adventure trails for children as
well as the iconic Supertree Grove. The tree-like structures that dominate the Gardens’ landscape that functions
as n environment engine for the gardens and lights up at night with music for a show of its own. Get up close to

the supertrees by exploring the OCBC skyway between the trees —— -
UP y exploring yway / “You can spend five lifetimes exploring nature,

Q 18 Marina Gardens Drive and there would still be more to learn.” says
Subaraj, who fell in love with the rainforest at the
age of 18, during a visit to Bukit Timah Reserve.
Singapore's blend of urban landscapes and
hidden ecosystems keeps him fighting against
rampant urbanisation: “In Singapore, you can
get from a five-star hotel to a rainforest in 20
minutes.”

He believes Singapore is the gateway to Asia, as
much as “it is that gateway for nature."

See Singapore through the eyes of a nature lover:
www.visitsingapore.com/en_my/see-do-singapore/
explorers/subaraj-rajathurai.html

UBIN BOTANIC GARDEN

singapore_query_005.client_description: are 7 young adults (ages 23-28) visiting Singapore for 4 days. They are interested in cultural heritage sites and traditional architecture, wellness activities and relaxation, botanical gardens and wildlife conservation

singapore_query_006.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 4 history buffs and museum lovers visiting Singapore for 3 days. They are interested in wellness activities and relaxation, modern art galleries and contemporary culture, educational experiences and guided tours. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_006.answer:
Day 1: Explore Singapore's rich history and culture
- Start the day with a walking tour of Chinatown, where you can immerse yourself in the underbelly of this historic district. Enjoy authentic traditional favorites such as Kopi-O, water cakes, and rice rolls.
- Visit the Singapore River and take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay, where you can hop onto a Bumboat Cruise and enjoy the beautiful views.
- Visit the Singapore River Museum to learn about the history of the river and its significance to Singapore.
- Visit the Singapore River Park for a relaxing walk and enjoy the beautiful views of the river.

Day 2: Explore modern art and contemporary culture
- Visit the National Gallery Singapore to see contemporary art exhibitions and learn about the city's vibrant art scene.
- Visit the Singapore Art Museum to see a variety of art exhibitions and learn about the city's rich cultural heritage.
- Visit the Singapore River Park for a relaxing walk and enjoy the beautiful views.

Day 3: Guided tours and wellness activities
- Take a guided tour of the Singapore River to learn about the history and significance of the river.
- Visit the Singapore River Park for a relaxing walk and enjoy the beautiful views.
- Visit the Singapore River Park for a wellness activity such as yoga or meditation.
- Visit the Singapore River Park for a guided tour of the park and learn about its history and significance.

Lighter Day for Recovery
- Visit the Singapore River Park for a leisurely walk and enjoy the beautiful views.
- Visit the Singapore River Park for a wellness activity such as yoga or meditation.
- Visit the Singapore River Park for a guided tour of the park and learn about its history and significance.

WALKING TOURS

Operated by The Chinatown Association, there's a
walking tour organised on every day of the week
that let you immerse yourself with the underbelly
of Chinatown. Move your senses with the sights
and sounds of hawkers cooking, coffee brewing
and locals bargain-hunting even as you taste
authentic traditional favourites such as Kopi-O,
water cakes and rice rolls in the "Good Morning,
Ni Hao" walking tour!

Explore the traditional customs that surround the
life of the early Chinese immigrant and discover
the reasons behind each practice in the "Passage
of Life: Birth, Marriage & Death” walking tour.

Visit Chinatown at sundown in the Nightout @
Chinatown Walking Tour, where the streets come
alive! Savour authentic Chinese food and test
your bargaining skills at the Street Market. Take a
leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop
onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.

® chinatown.sg

TRISHAW EXPEDITION
BY TRISHAW UNCLE

Say hello to uncle! Trishaw Uncle pays tribute to all
trishaw riders, for providing transport services rain or
shine, from the time before cars, buses and trains.

Embark on a trishaw expedition that takes you through
the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. Expect

a range of sights such as the Rex Cinema and Sri
Veeramakaliamman Temple and learn more about the
various roads such as Selegie Road and Serangoon
Road. Tours are available for Little India, Kampong
Glam, Chinatown as well the Singapore River.

® trishawuncle.com.sg

singapore_query_007.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 2 history buffs and museum lovers visiting Singapore for 4 days. They are interested in outdoor adventures, hiking trails, and nature parks, modern art galleries and contemporary culture. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_007.answer:
Day 1: Start your adventure with a visit to Fort Canning Park, where you can explore the history of Singapore and enjoy panoramic views of the city skyline. Afterward, head to the Southern Ridges for a scenic hike through Mount Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill, and HortPark. Finish the day with a visit to the Merlion Park, where you can enjoy the golden hour and take in the stunning views of the city's CBD.

Day 2: Begin your day with a visit to the Singapore Botanic Gardens, where you can explore the various gardens and learn about the city's natural history. Afterward, head to the Singapore River for a guided walk along the historic heritage lanes of Chinatown and Joo Chiat. End the day with a visit to the Singapore Art Museum, where you can explore modern art and contemporary culture.

Day 3: Start your day with a visit to the Singapore Zoo, where you can see a variety of animals and learn about their habitats. Afterward, head to the Singapore River for a trishaw expedition that takes you through the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. End the day with a visit to the Singapore River Cruise, where you can enjoy the beautiful views of the city skyline and take in the modern art installations along the river.

Day 4: Start your day with a visit to the Singapore River Cruise, where you can enjoy the beautiful views of the city skyline and take in the modern art installations along the river. Afterward, head to the Singapore River for a trishaw expedition that takes you through the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. End the day with a visit to the Singapore River Cruise, where you can enjoy the beautiful views of the city skyline and take in the modern art installations along the river.

Lighter Day: On the lighter day, you can visit the Singapore River for a trishaw expedition that takes you through the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. You can also visit the Singapore River Cruise, where you can enjoy the beautiful views of the city skyline and take in the modern art installations along the river.

contexts.text:
1/10 - SCENIC TRAILS TO RUN OR HIKE IN SINGAPORE /

SCENIC TR

MacRitchie Reservoir Park
Panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of

walking at 25 metres above ground are all part of the
experience when you traverse the TreeTop Walk, a
250-metre-long freestanding suspension bridge. See
first-hand the layers of the rainforest, from the ground
all the way to the canopy and the emergent layer of
trees, when you take on this scenic seven-kilometre-
long roundtrip to the bridge. From the carpark at Venus
Drive, it's a three- to four-hour hike—do note that the
TreeTop Walk only allows access from one direction.

Southern Ridges. Keep your camera on hand when
you hike the photogenic ten-kilometre-long network of
trails known as the Southern Ridges. The route starts
at HarbourFront Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) station and
takes you three to five hours to walk through Mount
Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill and HortPark before
ending at Kent Ridge Park. Soak in the scenic views

of our skyline and the Southern Islands at the peak of
Mount Faber Park, which is also where you can take
photos with the Merlion sculpture—one of seven that
dot the island. For Instagram-worthy pictures, we
definitely recommend Henderson Waves, the highest

pedestrian bridge in Singapore. The post-modern wood

and steel structure's also an ideal venue for a romantic
night stroll, as it's majestically illuminated by glowing
LED lights from 7pm to 7am.

Relive the footsteps of Malay kings and British
governors at Fort Canning Park. This area used to

be home to Malay royalty, and was also where Sir
Stamford Raffles built his first house, which eventually
became the place of residence for governors. Connect
with history when you explore Fort Canning Service
Reservoir to discover landmarks such as the nine-
pound cannon that dates back to the 19th century;
headstones that mark the site of Singapore's first
Christian cemetery; and Fort Gate, a remnant of the
fortress that was built on this hill.

IN SINGAPO

The golden hour washing over the city's CBD is a

sight to behold. Skyscrapers glimmer and Marina

Bay glistens—it all makes for a postcard-perfect
backdrop for your evening run. The area's proximity

to attractions, restaurants and heritage monuments
also means there's plenty to do and see after this

easy 3.9-kilometre route. Start at the Merlion Park
next to One Fullerton and you'll run past The Fullerton
Heritage precinct, across Marina Bay Sands. You can
cut through the underpass that connects the iconic
towers to Gardens by the Bay and whizz pask lakes and
conservatories before entering the Supertree Grove.
End your run with a last dash towards your final stop,
the Marina Barrage where Singapore's skyline lights up
to celebrate the completion of your run goal.

If there's one place in Singapore that's synonymous
with outdoor revelry, it's East Coast Park, where some
seven million locals and tourists flock to for the variety
of sporting, entertainment and dining attractions. Along
this 15-kiliometre stretch of beach, you'll find hordes
of cyclists and roller bladers enjoying the sun and sea
breeze, while cable skiing and water sports are on offer
for those who prefer wetter pursuits.

Sungai Buloh Wetlands Reserve. Enjoy an up-close
look at mud lobsters, tree-climbing crabs and monitor
lizards when you stroll along the 500-metre-long
boardwalk of the mangrove swamps in Sungei Buloh
Wetland Reserve. The boardwalk runs parallel to the
Wetland Centre. Look to the sky when you head to

the Migratory Bird Trail just a short walk away. From
behind the five hides, two platforms and the 18-metre-
tall Aerie Tower featured along the trail, you can

quietly observe migratory birds such as the Common
Redshank and Pacific Golden Plover that shack up in
this reserve from September to March. Kingfishers,
herons and egrets also visit the reserve regularly.

Bukit Timah is an expansive twist of roads and
buildings, but within the district are tranquil spots for
some quiet. Take
a hike up Bukit
Timah Hill or, for
the adventurous,
go off-tangent and
explore the jungles
of Bukit Timah
Nature Reserve by
mountain bike or
foot.

Punggol is a little far off from the city centre, but you'll
be surprised by the options awaiting you on this end
of the island. Explore the Punggol Waterway Park

by bicycle—there are scores of rental shops around
offering hourly rates—or meander the carved paths of
Coney Island.

singapore_query_008.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 5 senior travelers (ages 68-78) visiting Singapore for 4 days. They are interested in modern art galleries and contemporary culture, educational experiences and guided tours. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_008.answer:
Day 1: Explore Singapore's cultural heritage and historical landmarks. Start with a visit to the Singapore River, where you can take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River. Then, head to Fort Canning Park to learn about the history of Singapore and its Malay kings and British governors. After that, visit the Singapore River to see historical landmarks, guided walks in the various parks and gardens, and learn about the transformation of Singapore from a sleepy village into the metropolis it is today. Finally, end the day with a visit to the Singapore River to see historical landmarks, guided walks in the various parks and gardens, and learn about the transformation of Singapore from a sleepy village into the metropolis it is today.

Day 2: Take a scenic hike in Singapore's Southern Ridges. Start at HarbourFront Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) station and take a three to five-hour hike through Mount Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill, and HortPark before ending at Kent Ridge Park. Soak in the scenic views of our skyline and the Southern Islands at the peak of Mount Faber Park, which is also where you can take photos with the Merlion sculpture. For Instagram-worthy pictures, we definitely recommend Henderson Waves, the highest pedestrian bridge in Singapore. The post-modern wood and steel structure's also an ideal venue for a romantic night stroll, as it's majestically illuminated by glowing LED lights from 7pm to 7am.

Day 3: Take a scenic hike in Singapore's MacRitchie Reservoir Park. Start at the carpark at Venus Drive and take a three to four-hour hike to the TreeTop Walk, a 250-metre-long freestanding suspension bridge. See first-hand the layers of the rainforest, from the ground all the way to the canopy and the emergent layer of trees. For Instagram-worthy pictures, we definitely recommend Henderson Waves, the highest pedestrian bridge in Singapore. The post-modern wood and steel structure's also an ideal venue for a romantic night stroll, as it's majestically illuminated by glowing LED lights from 7pm to 7am.

Day 4: Take a scenic hike in Singapore's East Coast Park. Start at the Merlion Park next to One Fullerton and you'll run past The Fullerton Heritage precinct, across Marina Bay Sands. You can cut through the underpass that connects the iconic towers to Gardens by the Bay and whizz pask lakes and conservatories before entering the Supertree Grove. End your run with a last dash towards your final stop, the Marina Barrage where Singapore's skyline lights up to celebrate the completion of your run goal.

Lighter Day for Recovery: Take a scenic hike in Singapore's Bukit Timah Nature Reserve. Take a hike up Bukit Timah Hill or, for the adventurous, go off-tangent and explore the jungles of Bukit Timah Nature Reserve by mountain bike or foot.

1/10 - SCENIC TRAILS TO RUN OR HIKE IN SINGAPORE /

SCENIC TR

MacRitchie Reservoir Park
Panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of

walking at 25 metres above ground are all part of the
experience when you traverse the TreeTop Walk, a
250-metre-long freestanding suspension bridge. See
first-hand the layers of the rainforest, from the ground
all the way to the canopy and the emergent layer of
trees, when you take on this scenic seven-kilometre-
long roundtrip to the bridge. From the carpark at Venus
Drive, it's a three- to four-hour hike—do note that the
TreeTop Walk only allows access from one direction.

Southern Ridges. Keep your camera on hand when
you hike the photogenic ten-kilometre-long network of
trails known as the Southern Ridges. The route starts
at HarbourFront Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) station and
takes you three to five hours to walk through Mount
Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill and HortPark before
ending at Kent Ridge Park. Soak in the scenic views

of our skyline and the Southern Islands at the peak of
Mount Faber Park, which is also where you can take
photos with the Merlion sculpture—one of seven that
dot the island. For Instagram-worthy pictures, we
definitely recommend Henderson Waves, the highest

pedestrian bridge in Singapore. The post-modern wood

and steel structure's also an ideal venue for a romantic
night stroll, as it's majestically illuminated by glowing
LED lights from 7pm to 7am.

Relive the footsteps of Malay kings and British
governors at Fort Canning Park. This area used to

be home to Malay royalty, and was also where Sir
Stamford Raffles built his first house, which eventually
became the place of residence for governors. Connect
with history when you explore Fort Canning Service
Reservoir to discover landmarks such as the nine-
pound cannon that dates back to the 19th century;
headstones that mark the site of Singapore's first
Christian cemetery; and Fort Gate, a remnant of the
fortress that was built on this hill.

IN SINGAPO

The golden hour washing over the city's CBD is a

sight to behold. Skyscrapers glimmer and Marina

Bay glistens—it all makes for a postcard-perfect
backdrop for your evening run. The area's proximity

to attractions, restaurants and heritage monuments
also means there's plenty to do and see after this

easy 3.9-kilometre route. Start at the Merlion Park
next to One Fullerton and you'll run past The Fullerton
Heritage precinct, across Marina Bay Sands. You can
cut through the underpass that connects the iconic
towers to Gardens by the Bay and whizz pask lakes and
conservatories before entering the Supertree Grove.
End your run with a last dash towards your final stop,
the Marina Barrage where Singapore's skyline lights up
to celebrate the completion of your run goal.

If there's one place in Singapore that's synonymous
with outdoor revelry, it's East Coast Park, where some
seven million locals and tourists flock to for the variety
of sporting, entertainment and dining attractions. Along
this 15-kiliometre stretch of beach, you'll find hordes
of cyclists and roller bladers enjoying the sun and sea
breeze, while cable skiing and water sports are on offer
for those who prefer wetter pursuits.

Sungai Buloh Wetlands Reserve. Enjoy an up-close
look at mud lobsters, tree-climbing crabs and monitor
lizards when you stroll along the 500-metre-long
boardwalk of the mangrove swamps in Sungei Buloh
Wetland Reserve. The boardwalk runs parallel to the
Wetland Centre. Look to the sky when you head to

the Migratory Bird Trail just a short walk away. From
behind the five hides, two platforms and the 18-metre-
tall Aerie Tower featured along the trail, you can

quietly observe migratory birds such as the Common
Redshank and Pacific Golden Plover that shack up in
this reserve from September to March. Kingfishers,
herons and egrets also visit the reserve regularly.

Bukit Timah is an expansive twist of roads and
buildings, but within the district are tranquil spots for
some quiet. Take
a hike up Bukit
Timah Hill or, for
the adventurous,
go off-tangent and
explore the jungles
of Bukit Timah
Nature Reserve by
mountain bike or
foot.

Punggol is a little far off from the city centre, but you'll
be surprised by the options awaiting you on this end
of the island. Explore the Punggol Waterway Park

by bicycle—there are scores of rental shops around
offering hourly rates—or meander the carved paths of
Coney Island.

singapore_query_008.client_description: are 5 senior travelers (ages 68-78) visiting Singapore for 4 days. They are interested in modern art galleries and contemporary culture, educational experiences and guided tours

singapore_query_009.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 6 history buffs and museum lovers visiting Singapore for 6 days. They are interested in luxury experiences and fine dining, traditional crafts and cultural workshops, wellness activities and relaxation, ethnic neighborhoods like Chinatown and Little India. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_009.answer:
Day 1: Explore Singapore's rich history and culture
- Start your day with a visit to the Singapore Botanic Gardens, a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a beautiful garden to relax in.
- Visit the Singapore River and see historical landmarks, guided walks in the various parks and gardens.
- Take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.
- Visit the Singapore River Museum to learn about the history of the river and its significance to Singapore.
- End the day with a visit to the Singapore River Museum and enjoy a relaxing drink at a local café.

Day 2: Explore Chinatown and Little India
- Start your day with a visit to Chinatown, the oldest housing estate in Singapore, and explore the traditional customs that surround the life of the early Chinese immigrant.
- Visit the Singapore River and see historical landmarks, guided walks in the various parks and gardens.
- Take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.
- Visit the Singapore River Museum to learn about the history of the river and its significance to Singapore.
- End the day with a visit to Little India and experience the bustling hawker and "wet market" on its ground level with a battalion of rainbow-coloured textile and tailor shops up above.

Day 3: Explore Orchard Road and Tiong Bahru
- Start your day with a visit to Orchard Road, Asia's most famous shopping street, and explore the fashion favourites, specialist stores, and loads of other lifestyle choices.
- Visit the Singapore Visitor Centre and discover more places to explore and get help with ticketing and reservations.
- End the day with a visit to Tiong Bahru, the oldest housing estate in Singapore, and explore the food, shops, and culture.

Day 4: Explore the National Parks Board and Central Nature Reserve
- Start your day with a visit to the National Parks Board and Central Nature Reserve, where you can learn about the various parks and gardens and enjoy a relaxing walk.
- Visit the Singapore River and see historical landmarks, guided walks in the various parks and gardens.
- Take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.
- Visit the Singapore River Museum to learn about the history of the river and its significance to Singapore.
- End the day with a visit to the Singapore River Museum and enjoy a relaxing drink at a local café.

Day 5: Explore the Singapore River and Chinatown
- Start your day with a visit to the Singapore River and see historical landmarks, guided walks in the various parks and gardens.
- Take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.
- Visit the Singapore River Museum to learn about the history of the river and its significance to Singapore.
- End the day with a visit to Chinatown and explore the traditional customs that surround the life of the early Chinese immigrant.

Day 6: Lighter Day for Recovery
- Start your day with a visit to the Singapore River and see historical landmarks, guided walks in the various parks and gardens.
- Take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.
- Visit the Singapore River Museum to learn about the history of the river and its significance to Singapore.
- End the day with a visit to the Singapore River Museum and enjoy a relaxing drink at a local café.

1/02 - CONTENTS & A QUICK GUIDE TO SINGAPORE'S DISTRICTS /

A QUICK GUIDE

ORCHARD

Don't just sightsee, be an explorer. Orchard

Road, Asia's most famous shopping street, is

home to fashion favourites, specialist stores
and loads of other lifestyle choices. Today, Orchard
Road is flanked by iconic shopping malls, restaurants
and hotels, choc-a-bloc with retail, dining and enter-
tainment choice for every taste and budget.
The Singapore Visitor Centre is located on Orchard
Road just opposite Orchard Gateway. Discover more
places to explore and get help with ticketing and
reservations. Next to the centre is Emerald Hill Road,

lined with bars and clubs to wind down after a long day

of exploration. The east end of Orchard Road leads to
the Bras Basah and Fort Canning Park while the west
end of the street is just a stone's throw away from the
Singapore Botanic Gardens, the city's first and only

UNESCO World Heritage Site and a beautiful garden to

stop by.

Remember to make a detour to Dempsey Hill, one

of Singapore's most hip and quaint neighbourhoods,
nestled away in lush greenery just minutes from
Orchard Road. Here you'll be spoilt for choice for

the night's meal with options that include Michelin-
starred Candlenut, Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar, The
Disgruntled Chef. Or go green and experience Open
Farm Community's refreshing farm-to-table concept.

TIONG BAHRU

Tiong Bahru is the oldest housing estate

in Singapore, and when you visit this.

quaint community, you'll immediately
notice an intriguing mix of old and new. While many
older residents have lived in the shophouses and flats
here for decades, the younger generation flock here
for the food, shops, and culture. And as food goes,
the choices are abundant. From the sprawling Tiong
Bahru Market with its famous chwee kueh to the
hip Tiong Bahru Bakery, there are plenty of options
for a good meal in the morning. Fancy a coffee
and a quick bite? There are lots of cafés to choose
from — Forty Hands, Flock and cupcakes specialists
Plain Vanilla are just a few of them. It's a great place
to go for a spot of retail therapy, too. Independent
bookstore BooksActually stocks plenty of local
titles and retro knick-knacks, while Curated Records
offers a selection of vinyls, from rare vintage LPs to
mainstream hits.

LITTLE INDIA

Singapore's most colourful district, Little

India's bustling streets are a magnet for

explorers. From rows of shops exuding the
aroma of spices, to fortune-telling tables sprawled
along walkways, the precinct has stood as a cultural
vanguard of Singapore. Tucked away in its roads, you'll
find numerous landmarks of the city's many ethnic
and religious groups including the visually stunning
Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple, Kampong Kapor
Methodist Church, and the colourful expressions of
heritage at the House of Tan Teng Niah. Explore Little
India's heritage trail along its streets and back alleys,
and your eyes will be drawn to extravagant murals
showcasing Singapore's colourful past.

When you're done soaking in the sights and sounds,
to Tekka Centre and experience the bustling hawker
and “wet market” on its ground level with a battalion of
rainbow-coloured textile and tailor shops up above.

singapore_query_010.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are a family with teenagers aged 8 and 12 visiting Singapore for 6 days. - Check-in at the hotel
- Explore the city with a guided walking tour of Chinatown and Joo Chiat
- Visit a local hawker center for street food
- Relax at a wellness spa

Day 2: Exploring Singapore's Heritage
- Take a vintage Vespa tour through the heritage lanes of Chinatown and Joo Chiat
- Visit a local temple or mosque for a spiritual experience
- Enjoy a fine dining experience at a local restaurant
- Visit a hawker center for street food

Day 3: Exploring Singapore's Parks and Gardens
- Ride a bicycle through the National Parks Board parks and gardens
- Visit a local coffee shop for a relaxing hangout
- Explore a nature reserve for a wellness activity
- Relax at a wellness spa

Day 4: Exploring Singapore's Culinary Scene
- Visit a local cooking school for a cooking experience
- Explore a hawker center for street food
- Visit a local restaurant for a fine dining experience
- Relax at a wellness spa

Day 5: Exploring Singapore's Religious Sites
- Visit a local temple or mosque for a spiritual experience
- Explore a hawker center for street food
- Enjoy a fine dining experience at a local restaurant
- Relax at a wellness spa

Day 6: Lighter Day for Recovery
- Take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River
- Relax at a wellness spa
- Enjoy a leisurely breakfast at a local café
- Depart for home

singapore_query_011.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are a couple celebrating their retirement celebration visiting Singapore for 6 days. They are interested in traditional crafts and cultural workshops, modern art galleries and contemporary culture, botanical gardens and wildlife conservation. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_011.answer:
Day 1: Arrive in Singapore and check into your hotel. Spend the day exploring the city's attractions, such as the Singapore Botanic Garden, Gardens by the Bay, and the Singapore Zoo. Attend a traditional craft workshop or cultural event to learn about Singapore's rich history and culture.

Day 2: Visit the Singapore Art Museum and explore the city's modern art galleries. Take a stroll through the Singapore Botanic Garden and enjoy the beautiful botanical displays. Attend a wildlife conservation workshop or tour to learn about the city's efforts to protect its ecosystems.

Day 3: Take a scenic hike through the Southern Ridges or MacRitchie Reservoir Park to enjoy panoramic views of the city. Attend a contemporary culture event or workshop to learn about Singapore's vibrant arts scene.

Day 4: Visit the Singapore Botanic Garden and Gardens by the Bay to enjoy the beautiful botanical displays and modern art installations. Attend a traditional craft workshop or cultural event to learn about Singapore's rich history and culture.

Day 5: Take a leisurely walk along the East Coast Park or explore the Punggol Waterway Park to enjoy the beach and natural surroundings. Attend a wildlife conservation workshop or tour to learn about the city's efforts to protect its ecosystems.

Day 6: Spend the day relaxing and enjoying the city's cultural attractions, such as the Singapore Art Museum and Singapore Zoo. Attend a traditional craft workshop or cultural event to learn about Singapore's rich history and culture.

Lighter Day: Take a leisurely walk along the Singapore River or explore the Singapore Botanic Garden to enjoy the natural surroundings and relax. Attend a traditional craft workshop or cultural event to learn about Singapore's rich history and culture.

/ 08 - LITTLE EXPLORERS: BEING WITH MOTHER NATURE /

MEET
SUBARAJ RAJATHURAI

Many of Singapore's nature reserves exist due
" 4 to the efforts of a few individuals like Subaraj
Rajathurai: Self-taught naturalist and veteran

wildlife consultant. Over the last 35 years, he
GARDENS y
BY TH E BAY campaigned peacefully behind the scenes

to preserve some of Singapore's well-loved
ecosystems. In 1987, he and three others drafted
a proposal to save Sungei Buloh, a mangrove

Gardens by the Bay is a quick getaway to some serious greenery, a 101-ha horticultural park with two
conservatories, the Cloud Forest and the Flower Dome. The cool-moist conservatory that is the Cloud Forest
features a 35m-tall mountain covered in plants such as orchids and also sports the world's tallest indoor
waterfall. Meanwhile, the Flower Dome replicates a cool-dry climate and houses plants from the Mediterranean
region and also a Flower Field, where the displays change regularly.

forest in northwest Singapore which was slated
for redevelopment by the government. Thanks
to their perseverance, the wetland was declared
a nature park six years later. In 1992, Subaraj
was also part of the research team responsible
for saving the 123.8 hectares of forest at Lower
Peirce Reservoir.

While tickets are required for entry into the domes, the large three surrounding gardens are open to public to
enjoy. The highlight within the Bay South Garden is the Children's Garden filled with adventure trails for children as
well as the iconic Supertree Grove. The tree-like structures that dominate the Gardens’ landscape that functions
as n environment engine for the gardens and lights up at night with music for a show of its own. Get up close to

the supertrees by exploring the OCBC skyway between the trees —— -
UP y exploring yway / “You can spend five lifetimes exploring nature,

Q 18 Marina Gardens Drive and there would still be more to learn.” says
Subaraj, who fell in love with the rainforest at the
age of 18, during a visit to Bukit Timah Reserve.
Singapore's blend of urban landscapes and
hidden ecosystems keeps him fighting against
rampant urbanisation: “In Singapore, you can
get from a five-star hotel to a rainforest in 20
minutes.”

He believes Singapore is the gateway to Asia, as
much as “it is that gateway for nature."

See Singapore through the eyes of a nature lover:
www.visitsingapore.com/en_my/see-do-singapore/
explorers/subaraj-rajathurai.html

1/10 - SCENIC TRAILS TO RUN OR HIKE IN SINGAPORE /

SCENIC TR

MacRitchie Reservoir Park
Panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of

walking at 25 metres above ground are all part of the
experience when you traverse the TreeTop Walk, a
250-metre-long freestanding suspension bridge. See
first-hand the layers of the rainforest, from the ground
all the way to the canopy and the emergent layer of
trees, when you take on this scenic seven-kilometre-
long roundtrip to the bridge. From the carpark at Venus
Drive, it's a three- to four-hour hike—do note that the
TreeTop Walk only allows access from one direction.

Southern Ridges. Keep your camera on hand when
you hike the photogenic ten-kilometre-long network of
trails known as the Southern Ridges. The route starts
at HarbourFront Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) station and
takes you three to five hours to walk through Mount
Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill and HortPark before
ending at Kent Ridge Park. Soak in the scenic views

of our skyline and the Southern Islands at the peak of
Mount Faber Park, which is also where you can take
photos with the Merlion sculpture—one of seven that
dot the island. For Instagram-worthy pictures, we
definitely recommend Henderson Waves, the highest

pedestrian bridge in Singapore. The post-modern wood

and steel structure's also an ideal venue for a romantic
night stroll, as it's majestically illuminated by glowing
LED lights from 7pm to 7am.

Relive the footsteps of Malay kings and British
governors at Fort Canning Park. This area used to

be home to Malay royalty, and was also where Sir
Stamford Raffles built his first house, which eventually
became the place of residence for governors. Connect
with history when you explore Fort Canning Service
Reservoir to discover landmarks such as the nine-
pound cannon that dates back to the 19th century;
headstones that mark the site of Singapore's first
Christian cemetery; and Fort Gate, a remnant of the
fortress that was built on this hill.

IN SINGAPO

The golden hour washing over the city's CBD is a

sight to behold. Skyscrapers glimmer and Marina

Bay glistens—it all makes for a postcard-perfect
backdrop for your evening run. The area's proximity

to attractions, restaurants and heritage monuments
also means there's plenty to do and see after this

easy 3.9-kilometre route. Start at the Merlion Park
next to One Fullerton and you'll run past The Fullerton
Heritage precinct, across Marina Bay Sands. You can
cut through the underpass that connects the iconic
towers to Gardens by the Bay and whizz pask lakes and
conservatories before entering the Supertree Grove.
End your run with a last dash towards your final stop,
the Marina Barrage where Singapore's skyline lights up
to celebrate the completion of your run goal.

If there's one place in Singapore that's synonymous
with outdoor revelry, it's East Coast Park, where some
seven million locals and tourists flock to for the variety
of sporting, entertainment and dining attractions. Along
this 15-kiliometre stretch of beach, you'll find hordes
of cyclists and roller bladers enjoying the sun and sea
breeze, while cable skiing and water sports are on offer
for those who prefer wetter pursuits.

Sungai Buloh Wetlands Reserve. Enjoy an up-close
look at mud lobsters, tree-climbing crabs and monitor
lizards when you stroll along the 500-metre-long
boardwalk of the mangrove swamps in Sungei Buloh
Wetland Reserve. The boardwalk runs parallel to the
Wetland Centre. Look to the sky when you head to

the Migratory Bird Trail just a short walk away. From
behind the five hides, two platforms and the 18-metre-
tall Aerie Tower featured along the trail, you can

quietly observe migratory birds such as the Common
Redshank and Pacific Golden Plover that shack up in
this reserve from September to March. Kingfishers,
herons and egrets also visit the reserve regularly.

Bukit Timah is an expansive twist of roads and
buildings, but within the district are tranquil spots for
some quiet. Take
a hike up Bukit
Timah Hill or, for
the adventurous,
go off-tangent and
explore the jungles
of Bukit Timah
Nature Reserve by
mountain bike or
foot.

Punggol is a little far off from the city centre, but you'll
be surprised by the options awaiting you on this end
of the island. Explore the Punggol Waterway Park

by bicycle—there are scores of rental shops around
offering hourly rates—or meander the carved paths of
Coney Island.

SCENIC TR

singapore_query_011.client_description: are a couple celebrating their retirement celebration visiting Singapore for 6 days. They are interested in traditional crafts and cultural workshops, modern art galleries and contemporary culture, botanical gardens and wildlife conservation

singapore_query_012.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 4 business colleagues visiting Singapore for 6 days. They are interested in modern art galleries and contemporary culture, photography opportunities and scenic viewpoints. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_012.answer:
Day 1: Explore Singapore's colonial history and architecture at Fort Canning Park, Fort Canning Hill, and the Singapore Art Museum.
Day 2: Visit the National Gallery Singapore, the Asian Civilizations Museum, and the Singapore Art Museum to see modern art galleries and contemporary culture.
Day 3: Take a photography tour with a local photographer to capture the city's unique architecture and vibrant street scenes.
Day 4: Enjoy a leisurely day at Clarke Quay, Boat Quay, and Robertson Quay to take in the city's scenic views and enjoy modern art galleries and contemporary culture.
Day 5: Visit the Singapore Botanic Gardens and the Singapore Zoo to explore the city's natural beauty and learn about local wildlife.
Day 6: Take a light walking tour of Chinatown to experience the city's rich cultural heritage and enjoy local cuisine.

/ 09 - ACTIVITIES TO EXPLORE IN SINGAPORE /

If you need company while exploring

ACTIVITIES TO Shgepue heres ato messy
EXPLORE IN SINGAPORE “rite-ikna out ns woo

VESPA TOURS BY BETEL
BOX BACKPACKERS HOS
& TOURS AND SIDEWAYS

Dubbed the world's first vintage Vespa sidecar
tour service, jump into one of these charming
sidecars for an unforgettable tour. Explore the
heritage lanes of Chinatown and Joo Chiat, go on
a food and pub trail or view Singapore through a
photographer's lens.

) LET’S GO! NATIONAL
, BIKE SINGAPORE PARKS BOARD

The best way to know Singapore? Are you looking to bring your children out for a
On a bicycle! Ride on sidewalks and meaningful learning journey through Singapore's
quiet little streets that no bus tour can parks and gardens? The National Parks Board
get to. Meander along the Singapore organises a variety of different workshops and
River to see historical landmarks, guided walks in the various parks and gardens
museums and places of interest with the aim of creating a living learning

Pause at Singaporeans’ favourite environment that would enrich children. These
hangout: our humble ‘coffeeshop' to include activities around Central Nature Reserve,
try local drinks and snacks. Learn how Pulau Ubin, Fort Canning Park, The Southern
Singapore transformed from a sleepy Ridges and the Botanic Gardens.

village into the metropolis it is today. © nparks.govsg

‘4 @ letsgobikesingapore.com

CHINATOWN
WALKING TOURS

Operated by The Chinatown Association, there's a
walking tour organised on every day of the week
that let you immerse yourself with the underbelly
of Chinatown. Move your senses with the sights
and sounds of hawkers cooking, coffee brewing
and locals bargain-hunting even as you taste
authentic traditional favourites such as Kopi-O,
water cakes and rice rolls in the "Good Morning,
Ni Hao" walking tour!

Explore the traditional customs that surround the
life of the early Chinese immigrant and discover
the reasons behind each practice in the "Passage
of Life: Birth, Marriage & Death” walking tour.

Visit Chinatown at sundown in the Nightout @
Chinatown Walking Tour, where the streets come
alive! Savour authentic Chinese food and test
your bargaining skills at the Street Market. Take a
leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop
onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.

® chinatown.sg

TRISHAW EXPEDITION
BY TRISHAW UNCLE

Say hello to uncle! Trishaw Uncle pays tribute to all
trishaw riders, for providing transport services rain or
shine, from the time before cars, buses and trains.

Embark on a trishaw expedition that takes you through
the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. Expect

a range of sights such as the Rex Cinema and Sri
Veeramakaliamman Temple and learn more about the
various roads such as Selegie Road and Serangoon
Road. Tours are available for Little India, Kampong
Glam, Chinatown as well the Singapore River.

® trishawuncle.com.sg
