trishaw riders, for providing transport services rain or
shine, from the time before cars, buses and trains.

Embark on a trishaw expedition that takes you through
the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. Expect

a range of sights such as the Rex Cinema and Sri
Veeramakaliamman Temple and learn more about the
various roads such as Selegie Road and Serangoon
Road. Tours are available for Little India, Kampong
Glam, Chinatown as well the Singapore River.

® trishawuncle.com.sg

KAMPONG
GLAM

Some say Kampong Glam really is glam
(a local term meaning ‘glamorous’). The area has
an eclectic blend of history, culture and a super-
trendy lifestyle scene. Start from the landmark Sultan
Mosque, and wander through the many side streets.
The grounds of the former ‘Istana’ (‘palace’) to Sultan
Hussain Mohammed Shah is home to the Malay

103 - A QUICK GUIDE TO SINGAPORE’S DISTRICTS /

history and culture better. Wander the streets and you'll
soon uncover Haji Lane, a row of multi-label stores,
quirky boutiques as well as hip bars and cafes. Or pick
up traditional wares such as Persian carpets, kebaya
dresses and handmade perfumes from Arab Street and
Bussorah Street. The nasi padang (Indonesian dishes
flavoured with spices and served with rice) at Hjh
Maimunah is famous among locals. Café and boutique
Maison Ikkoku on Kandahar Street offers tasty
modern grub, and also houses an excellent rooftop

Heritage Centre, where you can get to know Malay cocktail bar.

JALAN BESAR,
ROCHER,
LAVENDER

Now a conserved area, Jalan Besar is home
to an eclectic range of eateries, cafés, entertainment
venues, and religious sites. It's also a hostel hotspot,
and backpackers constantly flock here. Beyond the
neon lights of bars and lounges, Jalan Besar is rife with
hip cafés that are now calling the neighbourhood's
many shophouses home. You can easily spend an
entire afternoon hopping from one spot to another
such as Chye Seng Huat Hardware, all while tucking
into hearty brunch plates, classic French pastries and
modern takes on local cuisine such as Non Entrée
Desserts. The district is also making a name for itself
as a haven for Third Wave coffee, so you will have
plenty of fuel for your trip.

THE CIVIC
DISTRICT

The Civic District is where Singapore's
historical, architectural and cultural heritage started.
Located right at the mouth of the Singapore River, the
Civic District is at the heart of the city's past, with key
landmarks from prominent historical figures such as Sir
Stamford Raffles, the man who founded Singapore, to
up-and-coming architectural icons of the 21st century.
Among key historical landmarks include St Andrew's
Cathedral, National Gallery Singapore which comprises
the historical Supreme Court and City Hall, Padang,
the Asian Civilisations Museum, The Arts House (Old
Parliament House) and Victoria Theatre, overlooking the
magnificent Fullerton Hotel and Esplanade - Theatres
on the Bay which locals affectionately call "the durian”.

BRAS BASAH BUGIS

Bras Basah.Bugis Precinct is where to go for a slice of Singapore's rich heritage, preserved

architecture and palpable energy. Head here for fine museums, national monuments and other

institutions, such as art schools and the Central Public Library. One of Singapore's oldest districts,
Bras Basah derived its name from the Malay term for ‘wet rice’ and Sir Stamford Raffles picked the area to be
the European center of Singapore Town. The adjacent Bugis Street, named after the seafaring Bugis people
from Indonesia who came here to trade with local merchants, has a less pristine past. You could spend days
just soaking in the vibe of this buzzing district. The district is home to museums such as the National Museum
of Singapore, The Singapore Art Museum and Peranakan Museum, and national monuments like the Armenian
Church and Central Fire Station, Singapore's oldest fire station. Explore CHIJMES, an enclave of restaurants and
bars in the middle of the city. The former chapel and school with its green lawns, marble waterfalls, courtyards
and neoclassical buildings — harks back to a bygone, more gracious age. A thriving district with a colourful past,
it now boasts everything shoppers could ever ask for; malls such as Bugis+ and Bugis Junction, charming
boutiques, bustling street markets, and of course, bargains at every corner.

THE COLONIAL
DISTRICT

Singapore's Colonial District is peppered with
reminders of British colonial rule. Together with Bras Basah
Bugis district and adjoining into the Civic District, it's the
centerpiece of Singapore surrounded by more modern
trappings that rise up around it. The district is anchored
by Fort Canning Park, an iconic hilltop landmark that has
witnessed many of Singapore's historical milestones. The
hill once sited the palaces of 14th century Malay Kings and
served as the Headquarters of the Far East Command Centre and British Army Barracks. Today, Fort Canning Park
is a venue for celebrations. Its expansive, sprawling lawns play host to concerts, theatre productions and festivals
such as Shakespeare in the Park, Ballet Under the Stars, and Films at the Fort, while weddings, parties and
gatherings are a regular sight in the park's venue spaces. Its ancient artefacts are a must-see for history buffs, and
its lush greenery and expansive lawns offer a variety of arts, heritage and nature experiences. Down the hill, you
can trace Singapore's history through stamps at the Singapore Philatelic Museum before stopping for lunch at the
Raffles Hotel. Raffles Hotel was the crown of colonial indulgence with a reputation of luxury. It is at this hotel's bar
where the legendary Singapore Sling was created

} THE QUAYS
ON SINGAPORE
RIVER

Consisting of a trio of Clarke Quay,
Robertson Quay and Boat Quay, you can literally
walk from the mouth of Singapore River through the
river valleys along some of the most pristine walking
paths. Shophouses along Boat Quay that used to
be the centre of trade has now been conserved and
adapted for modern use, offering up various bars,
‘ pubs and restaurants. Warehouses along Clarke
Quay are today Iconic dance clubs and live music
venues, rooftop bars, creating trendy nightspots for heart-pumping entertainment. Together, both Clarke Quay and
Boat Quay is a must-have stop for the city's most lively nightlife spots. As you move further inwards, Robertson Quay
offers a more quiet respite, with locals often seen running along its banks. The area combines upperclass residential
apartments with designer hotels such as M Social and The Warehouse Hotel with wonderful choices of gastronomic
options that would satisfy any foodie.

singapore_query_012.client_description: are 4 business colleagues visiting Singapore for 6 days. They are interested in modern art galleries and contemporary culture, photography opportunities and scenic viewpoints

singapore_query_013.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 5 nature and wildlife enthusiasts visiting Singapore for 6 days. They are interested in luxury experiences and fine dining, interactive science exhibits and STEM activities, cultural heritage sites and traditional architecture, innovative technology and futuristic attractions. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_013.answer:
Day 1: Explore the Southern Ridges and Fort Canning Park
Day 2: Visit MacRitchie Reservoir Park and Punggol Waterway Park
Day 3: Enjoy the beach and water sports at East Coast Park
Day 4: Relax at Sentosa Island and enjoy the fun and entertainment
Day 5: Take a hike up Bukit Timah Hill or explore the jungles of Bukit Timah Nature Reserve
Day 6: Lighter day for recovery and cultural heritage sites such as the Masjid Al-Albrar and the Ann Siang Hill area
Day 7: Leisurely day at Sentosa Island or explore the cultural heritage sites such as the Masjid Al-Albrar and the Ann Siang Hill area.

became the place of residence for governors. Connect
with history when you explore Fort Canning Service
Reservoir to discover landmarks such as the nine-
pound cannon that dates back to the 19th century;
headstones that mark the site of Singapore's first
Christian cemetery; and Fort Gate, a remnant of the
fortress that was built on this hill.

IN SINGAPO

The golden hour washing over the city's CBD is a

sight to behold. Skyscrapers glimmer and Marina

Bay glistens—it all makes for a postcard-perfect
backdrop for your evening run. The area's proximity

to attractions, restaurants and heritage monuments
also means there's plenty to do and see after this

easy 3.9-kilometre route. Start at the Merlion Park
next to One Fullerton and you'll run past The Fullerton
Heritage precinct, across Marina Bay Sands. You can
cut through the underpass that connects the iconic
towers to Gardens by the Bay and whizz pask lakes and
conservatories before entering the Supertree Grove.
End your run with a last dash towards your final stop,
the Marina Barrage where Singapore's skyline lights up
to celebrate the completion of your run goal.

If there's one place in Singapore that's synonymous
with outdoor revelry, it's East Coast Park, where some
seven million locals and tourists flock to for the variety
of sporting, entertainment and dining attractions. Along
this 15-kiliometre stretch of beach, you'll find hordes
of cyclists and roller bladers enjoying the sun and sea
breeze, while cable skiing and water sports are on offer
for those who prefer wetter pursuits.

Sungai Buloh Wetlands Reserve. Enjoy an up-close
look at mud lobsters, tree-climbing crabs and monitor
lizards when you stroll along the 500-metre-long
boardwalk of the mangrove swamps in Sungei Buloh
Wetland Reserve. The boardwalk runs parallel to the
Wetland Centre. Look to the sky when you head to

the Migratory Bird Trail just a short walk away. From
behind the five hides, two platforms and the 18-metre-
tall Aerie Tower featured along the trail, you can

quietly observe migratory birds such as the Common
Redshank and Pacific Golden Plover that shack up in
this reserve from September to March. Kingfishers,
herons and egrets also visit the reserve regularly.

Bukit Timah is an expansive twist of roads and
buildings, but within the district are tranquil spots for
some quiet. Take
a hike up Bukit
Timah Hill or, for
the adventurous,
go off-tangent and
explore the jungles
of Bukit Timah
Nature Reserve by
mountain bike or
foot.

Punggol is a little far off from the city centre, but you'll
be surprised by the options awaiting you on this end
of the island. Explore the Punggol Waterway Park

by bicycle—there are scores of rental shops around
offering hourly rates—or meander the carved paths of
Coney Island.

710 - SCENIC TRAILS TO RUN OR HIKE IN SINGAPORE /

SCENIC TR

MacRitchie Reservoir Park
Panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of

walking at 25 metres above ground are all part of the
experience when you traverse the TreeTop Walk, a
250-metre-long freestanding suspension bridge. See
first-hand the layers of the rainforest, from the ground
all the way to the canopy and the emergent layer of
trees, when you take on this scenic seven-kilometre-
long roundtrip to the bridge. From the carpark at Venus
Drive, it's a three- to four-hour hike—do note that the
TreeTop Walk only allows access from one direction.

Southern Ridges. Keep your camera on hand when
you hike the photogenic ten-kilometre-long network of
trails known as the Southern Ridges. The route starts
at HarbourFront Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) station and
takes you three to five hours to walk through Mount
Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill and HortPark before
ending at Kent Ridge Park. Soak in the scenic views

of our skyline and the Southern Islands at the peak of
Mount Faber Park, which is also where you can take
photos with the Merlion sculpture—one of seven that
dot the island. For Instagram-worthy pictures, we
definitely recommend Henderson Waves, the highest

pedestrian bridge in Singapore. The post-modern wood

and steel structure's also an ideal venue for a romantic
night stroll, as it's majestically illuminated by glowing
LED lights from 7pm to 7am.

governors at Fort Canning Park. This area used to

1 04- A QUICK GUIDE TO SINGAPORE'S DISTRICTS /

MARINA BAY

The marquee of modern Singapore

for everything glitz and glam,

Marina Bay has it all. Home to some
of Singapore's most iconic structures (think the
Singapore Flyer, Marina Bay Sands and Gardens by
the Bay), it is the ultimate playground for those seeking
to indulge. Treat yourself to a satisfying meal at one
of the many celebrity restaurants in Marina Bay Sands
or end your night by partying at a trendy rooftop club.
With the FORMULA 1® race transforming this glittering
waterfront venue into the pulsating heart of the action,
there really is no better place to be.

DOWNTOWN
CORE

The financial heart of Singapore,

Downtown Core houses corporate headquarters and
financial institutions such as the Singapore Exchange
and is home to the Central Business District. It's made
out of seven subzones, Anson, Cecil, Clifford Pier,
Maxwell, Phillip, Raffles Place and Tanjong Pagar.
Tanjong Pagar is the first area in Singapore to be
gazetted under a conservation plan of heritage zones.
In recent years, the neighborhood has enjoyed a revival,
emerging as the epicenter for today's global traveler
as one of the island's most stylish leisure and dining
neighborhoods. Among them, Tras Street is lined with
restaurants, speakeasies and bars for those in the know.

A long-standing landmark in the heart of the
Central Business District, Lau Pa Sat is a long-standing
landmark in the heart of the central business district and
has witnessed Singapore's ever-changing landscape,
from mudflats to metropolis. The 120-year-old market is
amuch frequented destination for hawker food amidst
soaring arches and Victorian era columns.

CHINATOWN

Singapore's historic Chinatown is a bustling mix of old and new, filled with traditional shops and
markets as well as cool stores and cafes. Tea and opera houses, as well as opium dens, were the
most popular forms of entertainment back in the olden days, and the Chinatown Street Market
was where people congregated to shop, eat and socialise. Yet pockets of history remain in Chinatown, along with
more modern sights. You could easily spend a few days wandering through these still-narrow streets. Family-
run goldsmiths, medicinal halls and teahouses ply their trades next to sleeker neighbours such as hipster bars.
and lifestyle shops. Thian Hock Keng temple at Telok Ayer Street is the oldest Chinese temple in Singapore.
Right along the same street is the Masjid Al-Albrar, one of the earliest mosques in Singapore. Just a few streets
away at South Bridge Road is the Sri r 7
Mariamman temple, the oldest Hindu
temple in the country.
Amoy Street Food Centre can
boast as a reputable spot to savour
some of the city's street-food staples,
with not one, two, or three, but four stalls
making into the list of 2017 Michelin Bib
Gourmand Singapore. How much Bib
Gourmand can you taste in one sitting?
For trendier tastes, chic restaurants and
bars are in Neil Road, Duxton Road and
Keong Saik Road, with the latter being he 4
named #4 on Lonely Planet must visit places in Asia. If Clarke Quay is the party central of Singapore, then the
Ann Siang Hill and Club Street area is its cool, younger cousin — equally fun and always fully charged with an
electrifying atmosphere after dark, a favourite with people in the know of the latest nightlife destinations.

» EAST OF SINGAPORE

The beautiful, historic-rich Joo Chiat/Katong
neighbourhood is often admired for its colourful rows of
Peranakan (Straits-born people of Chinese and Malay/
Indonesian heritage) shophouses. What you might not
know: this neighbourhood is as loved for its variety of
food options as it is for its architecture. Start by making
a pit stop at the 328 Katong Laksa that offers this
neighbourhood's most famous signature dish, the Katong
Laksa, having competed with Gordon Ramsay in 2013
and won. Stop by The Intan, a living museum dedicated to
Peranakan culture operated by a lively curator, where by appointment would allow you to immerse into the home of
a Peranakan family, complete with artifacts and food shared over stories of heritage. Discover Peranakan culture as
you stroll past heritage shophouses, quaint stores and eateries in this charming corner of eastern Singapore.
Historic architecture, cultural diversity, and cult-status eateries are accolades not commonly associated with
Singapore's Geylang district-which is frequently written off as the island's infamous nightlife zone. But take a stroll
through the meandering lanes and bustling back alleys of this unique enclave, and you'll find a buzzing hub filled
with colourful shophouses, mosques, temples, bars and more that put Geylang firmly on the explorer's trail. This is
as authentic as you can get to local food and culture through hawker centres and illuminated night markets.

WEST
SINGAPORE

For those who want to get
away from — and above - the city and a little
closer to nature, the Southern Ridges is a great
place to explore. As a bonus, you will also get
one of the best panoramic views of the city,
harbour and the Southern Islands. The Southern
Ridges is a 10-kilometre stretch of green open
spaces spanning the hills of some of Singapore's
most popular parks and gardens, connected
by picturesque ridges and pathways. Imagine
walking across a bridge 36-metres above the road
connecting two hilltops. You can perform this
exhilarating high-wire act at Henderson Waves,
a distinctive wave-like structure consisting of a
series of undulating curved ‘ribs’, also Singapore's
highest pedestrian bridge. The Southern Ridges is
made up of Mount Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill
Park, HortPark, Kent Ridge Park and Labrador
Nature Reserve. Further west takes you to
Singapore Discovery Centre and the Lee Kong
Chian Natural History Museum.

SENTOSA

Singapore's favourite playground lies in the southern coast where
you'll find all the entertainment you need for all ages on this island,
where the fun doesn't cease and boredom retreats. Whether you're

in search of thrills and spills or a relaxed beachside afternoon, you will be spoilt for

choice at Singapore's favourite leisure destination.

From crowd-pleasing attractions like Universal Studios Singapore and

Adventure Cove Waterpark to the magical marine world at the S.E.A Aquarium

at Resorts World™ Sentosa, this bustling island will not disappoint. Beyond the

integrated resort, soak up the sun on the 3.2km long beach and the many outdoor

facilities. Test your wits at

the Skyline Luge or your

wills at Mega Adventure

before making a dive at the

indoor skydiving wind tunnel

at iFly Singapore. You can

either take the Singapore

Cable Car for a breaktaking

view of the South China Sea

or retreat to Quayside Isle

at Sentosa Cove for a much

needed respite from the

day's adrenaline rush.

be

singapore_query_013.client_description: are 5 nature and wildlife enthusiasts visiting Singapore for 6 days. They are interested in luxury experiences and fine dining, interactive science exhibits and STEM activities, cultural heritage sites and traditional architecture, innovative technology and futuristic attractions

singapore_query_014.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are a couple celebrating their anniversary visiting Singapore for 5 days. They are interested in colonial architecture and historical landmarks, outdoor adventures, hiking trails, and nature parks, modern art galleries and contemporary culture, maritime history and waterfront attractions. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_014.answer:
Day 1: Arrive in Singapore and settle in your hotel. Take a guided tour of Fort Canning Park to explore colonial architecture and historical landmarks. Visit the Merlion Park and Gardens by the Bay for a scenic walk and enjoy the waterfront attractions.

Day 2: Start your day with a visit to the Singapore Botanic Gardens to explore the modern art galleries and contemporary culture. Take a guided tour of the Singapore River to learn about maritime history and enjoy the waterfront attractions. In the afternoon, hike the Southern Ridges for a scenic hike and nature park experience. End the day with a relaxing walk along the boardwalk of Sungei Buloh Wetland Reserve.

Day 3: Start your day with a visit to the Singapore River to learn about maritime history and enjoy the waterfront attractions. Take a guided tour of the Singapore Botanic Gardens to explore the modern art galleries and contemporary culture. In the afternoon, hike the Bukit Timah Hill for a tranquil hike and nature park experience. End the day with a guided tour of Chinatown to immerse yourself with the underbelly of Chinatown.

Day 4: Start your day with a visit to the Singapore Botanic Gardens to explore the modern art galleries and contemporary culture. Take a guided tour of the Singapore River to learn about maritime history and enjoy the waterfront attractions. In the afternoon, hike the Bukit Timah Hill for a tranquil hike and nature park experience. End the day with a guided tour of Chinatown to immerse yourself with the underbelly of Chinatown.

Day 5: Start your day with a visit to the Singapore Botanic Gardens to explore the modern art galleries and contemporary culture. Take a guided tour of the Singapore River to learn about maritime history and enjoy the waterfront attractions. In the afternoon, hike the Bukit Timah Hill for a tranquil hike and nature park experience. End the day with a guided tour of Chinatown to immerse yourself with the underbelly of Chinatown.

Lighter Day: Take a guided tour of the Singapore Botanic Gardens to explore the modern art galleries and contemporary culture. Enjoy a leisurely walk along the boardwalk of Sungei Buloh Wetland Reserve for a relaxing nature park experience.

VESPA TOURS BY BETEL
BOX BACKPACKERS HOS
& TOURS AND SIDEWAYS

Dubbed the world's first vintage Vespa sidecar
tour service, jump into one of these charming
sidecars for an unforgettable tour. Explore the
heritage lanes of Chinatown and Joo Chiat, go on
a food and pub trail or view Singapore through a
photographer's lens.

) LET’S GO! NATIONAL

The best way to know Singapore? Are you looking to bring your children out for a

quiet little streets that no bus tour can parks and gardens? The National Parks Board
get to. Meander along the Singapore organises a variety of different workshops and

village into the metropolis it is today. © nparks.govsg

‘4 @ letsgobikesingapore.com

CHINATOWN
WALKING TOURS

Operated by The Chinatown Association, there's a
walking tour organised on every day of the week
that let you immerse yourself with the underbelly
of Chinatown. Move your senses with the sights
and sounds of hawkers cooking, coffee brewing
and locals bargain-hunting even as you taste
authentic traditional favourites such as Kopi-O,
water cakes and rice rolls in the "Good Morning,
Ni Hao" walking tour!

Explore the traditional customs that surround the
life of the early Chinese immigrant and discover
the reasons behind each practice in the "Passage
of Life: Birth, Marriage & Death” walking tour.

Visit Chinatown at sundown in the Nightout @
Chinatown Walking Tour, where the streets come
alive! Savour authentic Chinese food and test
your bargaining skills at the Street Market. Take a
leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop
onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.

® chinatown.sg

TRISHAW EXPEDITION
BY TRISHAW UNCLE

Say hello to uncle! Trishaw Uncle pays tribute to all
trishaw riders, for providing transport services rain or
shine, from the time before cars, buses and trains.

Embark on a trishaw expedition that takes you through
the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. Expect

a range of sights such as the Rex Cinema and Sri
Veeramakaliamman Temple and learn more about the
various roads such as Selegie Road and Serangoon
Road. Tours are available for Little India, Kampong
Glam, Chinatown as well the Singapore River.

® trishawuncle.com.sg

singapore_query_014.client_description: are a couple celebrating their anniversary visiting Singapore for 5 days. They are interested in colonial architecture and historical landmarks, outdoor adventures, hiking trails, and nature parks, modern art galleries and contemporary culture, maritime history and waterfront attractions

singapore_query_015.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 6 senior travelers (ages 62-72) visiting Singapore for 4 days. They are interested in ethnic neighborhoods like Chinatown and Little India, family-friendly attractions and theme parks, maritime history and waterfront attractions. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_015.answer:
Day 1: Explore Chinatown and Little India
- Start your day with a walking tour of Chinatown, where you can immerse yourself in the underbelly of this vibrant neighborhood. Enjoy authentic traditional favorites such as Kopi-O, water cakes, and rice rolls.
- Visit Little India, known for its bustling streets and cultural landmarks. Explore the Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple, Kampong Kapor Methodist Church, and the House of Tan Teng Niah.
- In the evening, enjoy a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.

Day 2: Family-Friendly Attractions and Theme Parks
- Visit the Singapore Zoo, which offers a variety of animal exhibits and educational programs for families.
- Take a stroll through the Singapore Botanic Gardens, which features a diverse range of plant species and stunning landscapes.
- Visit the Singapore River, where you can take a boat tour or enjoy a leisurely walk along the waterfront.

Day 3: Maritime History and Waterfront Attractions
- Visit the Fort Canning Park, which offers stunning views of the Singapore River and the city skyline.
- Take a boat tour along the Singapore River, which offers a unique perspective of the city's history and culture.
- Explore the Singapore Riverfront, which features a variety of restaurants, bars, and entertainment options.

Day 4: Lighter Day for Recovery
- Take a leisurely walk along the Singapore River, taking in the beautiful scenery and enjoying the fresh air.
- Visit the Singapore Riverfront, where you can relax and enjoy a variety of food and drinks.
- End your day with a visit to the Singapore Visitor Centre, where you can learn more about the city's history and attractions.

and sounds of hawkers cooking, coffee brewing

Say hello to uncle! Trishaw Uncle pays tribute to all
trishaw riders, for providing transport services rain or
shine, from the time before cars, buses and trains.

Embark on a trishaw expedition that takes you through
the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. Expect

a range of sights such as the Rex Cinema and Sri
Veeramakaliamman Temple and learn more about the
various roads such as Selegie Road and Serangoon
Road. Tours are available for Little India, Kampong
Glam, Chinatown as well the Singapore River.

1/02 - CONTENTS & A QUICK GUIDE TO SINGAPORE'S DISTRICTS /

A QUICK GUIDE

ORCHARD

Don't just sightsee, be an explorer. Orchard

Road, Asia's most famous shopping street, is

home to fashion favourites, specialist stores
and loads of other lifestyle choices. Today, Orchard
Road is flanked by iconic shopping malls, restaurants
and hotels, choc-a-bloc with retail, dining and enter-
tainment choice for every taste and budget.
The Singapore Visitor Centre is located on Orchard
Road just opposite Orchard Gateway. Discover more
places to explore and get help with ticketing and
reservations. Next to the centre is Emerald Hill Road,

lined with bars and clubs to wind down after a long day

of exploration. The east end of Orchard Road leads to
the Bras Basah and Fort Canning Park while the west
end of the street is just a stone's throw away from the
Singapore Botanic Gardens, the city's first and only

UNESCO World Heritage Site and a beautiful garden to

stop by.

Remember to make a detour to Dempsey Hill, one

of Singapore's most hip and quaint neighbourhoods,
nestled away in lush greenery just minutes from
Orchard Road. Here you'll be spoilt for choice for

the night's meal with options that include Michelin-
starred Candlenut, Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar, The
Disgruntled Chef. Or go green and experience Open
Farm Community's refreshing farm-to-table concept.

TIONG BAHRU

Tiong Bahru is the oldest housing estate

in Singapore, and when you visit this.

quaint community, you'll immediately
notice an intriguing mix of old and new. While many
older residents have lived in the shophouses and flats
here for decades, the younger generation flock here
for the food, shops, and culture. And as food goes,
the choices are abundant. From the sprawling Tiong
Bahru Market with its famous chwee kueh to the
hip Tiong Bahru Bakery, there are plenty of options
for a good meal in the morning. Fancy a coffee
and a quick bite? There are lots of cafés to choose
from — Forty Hands, Flock and cupcakes specialists
Plain Vanilla are just a few of them. It's a great place
to go for a spot of retail therapy, too. Independent
bookstore BooksActually stocks plenty of local
titles and retro knick-knacks, while Curated Records
offers a selection of vinyls, from rare vintage LPs to
mainstream hits.

LITTLE INDIA

Singapore's most colourful district, Little

India's bustling streets are a magnet for

explorers. From rows of shops exuding the
aroma of spices, to fortune-telling tables sprawled
along walkways, the precinct has stood as a cultural
vanguard of Singapore. Tucked away in its roads, you'll
find numerous landmarks of the city's many ethnic
and religious groups including the visually stunning
Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple, Kampong Kapor
Methodist Church, and the colourful expressions of
heritage at the House of Tan Teng Niah. Explore Little
India's heritage trail along its streets and back alleys,
and your eyes will be drawn to extravagant murals
showcasing Singapore's colourful past.

When you're done soaking in the sights and sounds,
to Tekka Centre and experience the bustling hawker
and “wet market” on its ground level with a battalion of
rainbow-coloured textile and tailor shops up above.

singapore_query_016.client_description: are 5 young adults (ages 22-26) visiting Singapore for 6 days. They are interested in photography opportunities and scenic viewpoints, cultural heritage sites and traditional architecture, interactive science exhibits and STEM activities, maritime history and waterfront attractions

singapore_query_017.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 6 young adults (ages 26-32) visiting Singapore for 3 days. They are interested in religious sites and spiritual experiences, innovative technology and futuristic attractions, maritime history and waterfront attractions. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_017.answer:
Day 1: Explore Singapore's religious sites and spiritual experiences. Visit the Singapore Botanic Gardens, the Singapore Zoo, and the Singapore Art Museum. Take a walk through the Singapore Botanic Gardens and enjoy the beautiful gardens and the Singapore Zoo. Visit the Singapore Art Museum and enjoy the art exhibits. In the evening, take a stroll along the Singapore River and enjoy the beautiful views.

Day 2: Visit the Singapore Science Centre and the Singapore Science Museum. These museums are great for young adults who are interested in technology and futuristic attractions. Take a tour of the Singapore Science Centre and learn about the latest in technology. Visit the Singapore Science Museum and learn about the history of science. In the evening, take a stroll along the Singapore River and enjoy the beautiful views.

Day 3: Visit the Singapore River and the Singapore River Cruise. These attractions are great for young adults who are interested in maritime history and waterfront attractions. Take a tour of the Singapore River and learn about the history of the river. Take a cruise along the Singapore River and enjoy the beautiful views. In the evening, take a stroll along the Singapore River and enjoy the beautiful views.

Day 4: Take a light walk in Chinatown and visit the Singapore Zoo. This is a great day for recovery and relaxation. Take a light walk in Chinatown and enjoy the beautiful views. Visit the Singapore Zoo and enjoy the animals. In the evening, take a stroll along the Singapore River and enjoy the beautiful views.

singapore_query_017.client_description: are 6 young adults (ages 26-32) visiting Singapore for 3 days. They are interested in religious sites and spiritual experiences, innovative technology and futuristic attractions, maritime history and waterfront attractions

singapore_query_018.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are a family of 4 with children aged 6 and 10 visiting Singapore for 5 days. They are interested in photography opportunities and scenic viewpoints, modern art galleries and contemporary culture, innovative technology and futuristic attractions. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_018.answer:
Day 1: Arrival and Exploration
- Arrive in Singapore and check into your hotel
- Visit the National Gallery Singapore for a tour of the contemporary art galleries and contemporary culture
- Take a walk around the Singapore River and enjoy the scenic views
- Have a light lunch at a local café or food court

Day 2: Photography and Scenic Views
- Take a Vespa tour through the heritage lanes of Chinatown and Joo Chiat
- Visit the Singapore River and take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay
- Enjoy a Bumboat Cruise along the Singapore River
- Have a light lunch at a local café or food court

Day 3: Modern Art Galleries and Contemporary Culture
- Visit the National Gallery Singapore for a tour of the contemporary art galleries and contemporary culture
- Explore the Singapore River and enjoy the scenic views
- Have a light lunch at a local café or food court

Day 4: Innovation and Futurism
- Visit the Singapore Science Centre for a tour of the innovative technology and futuristic attractions
- Take a walk around the Singapore River and enjoy the scenic views
- Have a light lunch at a local café or food court

Day 5: Lighter Day for Recovery
- Take a walk around the Singapore River and enjoy the scenic views
- Have a light lunch at a local café or food court
- Spend the afternoon relaxing and enjoying the city's vibrant atmosphere

Note: This itinerary is designed to provide a mix of activities that cater to the interests of the family, while also allowing for some downtime for recovery.

LITTLE EXPLORERS:
S PA R Kl N G Childhood is a time of natural creativity and curiosity. While in

Singapore, explore some key highlights that gets your child out of

C R EAT IV | TY the comforts of four walls and engage them with a multitude of
sensory experiences that would spark bundles of creative energy.

NATIONAL GALLERY

SINGAPORE is the labour of love

transforming the historical Supreme Court
building and the City Hall into the largest art museum
in Singapore focusing on Southeast Asian art. What
sets it apart is the multitude of kid-friendly exhibits
and installations including the Keppel Centre that
work to instill art appreciation at a young age.
Exhibitions at the the National Gallery changes by
season and is currently showing the Children's
Biennale — until 8 Oct 2017. The first edition of
the Gallery Children's Biennale, a four-month-long KEPPEL CENTRE The newly refreshed Keppel Centre is an exciting space where art
festival organised by the Gallery, invites you to FOR ART inspires new ways of learning. Visitors can enjoy immersive spaces
discover art in a whole new way. Explore dreams EDUCATION AT that encourage imagination, creativity and self-led exploration. The
and stories through site-specific installations, Keppel Centre also provides a lively line-up of programmes for youth,
interactive artworks and a stimulating line-up of NATIONAL GALLERY children and families all year round. This creates opportunities for
music performances, film showcases and art- SINGAPORE parents to bond with their little ones through the arts and stimulates

singapore_query_019.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 2 history buffs and museum lovers visiting Singapore for 7 days. They are interested in botanical gardens and wildlife conservation, cultural heritage sites and traditional architecture. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_019.answer:
Day 1: Arrive in Singapore and check into your hotel. Visit Fort Canning Park to learn about the history of Singapore and its role as a British colony. Take a stroll through the Botanic Gardens to admire the diverse flora and fauna.

Day 2: Visit the Singapore Botanic Gardens to explore the various exhibits and learn about the city's rich botanical heritage. Take a guided tour of the gardens to learn about the conservation efforts and the importance of preserving Singapore's natural ecosystems.

Day 3: Explore the Singapore Zoo to see a variety of animals from around the world. Take a guided tour of the zoo to learn about the conservation efforts and the importance of protecting endangered species.

Day 4: Visit the National Orchid Garden to see a large display of orchids and learn about the history of orchid cultivation in Singapore. Take a guided tour of the garden to learn about the conservation efforts and the importance of preserving orchids.

Day 5: Take a guided tour of the Singapore River to learn about the city's history and the importance of preserving its natural ecosystems. Visit the Singapore River Park to learn about the city's efforts to restore the river and its surrounding areas.

Day 6: Visit the Singapore Art Museum to learn about the city's cultural heritage and the importance of preserving its artistic heritage. Take a guided tour of the museum to learn about the exhibits and the history of Singapore's art scene.

Day 7: Take a guided tour of the Singapore Botanic Gardens to learn about the conservation efforts and the importance of preserving Singapore's natural ecosystems. Visit the Singapore Zoo to see a variety of animals from around the world.

Lighter Day: Take a guided tour of the Singapore Botanic Gardens to learn about the conservation efforts and the importance of preserving Singapore's natural ecosystems. Visit the Singapore Zoo to see a variety of animals from around the world.

contexts.text:
/ 08 - LITTLE EXPLORERS: BEING WITH MOTHER NATURE /

MEET
SUBARAJ RAJATHURAI

Many of Singapore's nature reserves exist due
" 4 to the efforts of a few individuals like Subaraj
Rajathurai: Self-taught naturalist and veteran

wildlife consultant. Over the last 35 years, he
GARDENS y
BY TH E BAY campaigned peacefully behind the scenes

to preserve some of Singapore's well-loved
ecosystems. In 1987, he and three others drafted
a proposal to save Sungei Buloh, a mangrove

Gardens by the Bay is a quick getaway to some serious greenery, a 101-ha horticultural park with two
conservatories, the Cloud Forest and the Flower Dome. The cool-moist conservatory that is the Cloud Forest
features a 35m-tall mountain covered in plants such as orchids and also sports the world's tallest indoor
waterfall. Meanwhile, the Flower Dome replicates a cool-dry climate and houses plants from the Mediterranean
region and also a Flower Field, where the displays change regularly.

forest in northwest Singapore which was slated
for redevelopment by the government. Thanks
to their perseverance, the wetland was declared
a nature park six years later. In 1992, Subaraj
was also part of the research team responsible
for saving the 123.8 hectares of forest at Lower
Peirce Reservoir.

While tickets are required for entry into the domes, the large three surrounding gardens are open to public to
enjoy. The highlight within the Bay South Garden is the Children's Garden filled with adventure trails for children as
well as the iconic Supertree Grove. The tree-like structures that dominate the Gardens’ landscape that functions
as n environment engine for the gardens and lights up at night with music for a show of its own. Get up close to

the supertrees by exploring the OCBC skyway between the trees —— -
UP y exploring yway / “You can spend five lifetimes exploring nature,

Q 18 Marina Gardens Drive and there would still be more to learn.” says
Subaraj, who fell in love with the rainforest at the
age of 18, during a visit to Bukit Timah Reserve.
Singapore's blend of urban landscapes and
hidden ecosystems keeps him fighting against
rampant urbanisation: “In Singapore, you can
get from a five-star hotel to a rainforest in 20
minutes.”

He believes Singapore is the gateway to Asia, as
much as “it is that gateway for nature."

See Singapore through the eyes of a nature lover:
www.visitsingapore.com/en_my/see-do-singapore/
explorers/subaraj-rajathurai.html

UBIN BOTANIC GARDEN

1/10 - SCENIC TRAILS TO RUN OR HIKE IN SINGAPORE /

SCENIC TR

MacRitchie Reservoir Park
Panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of

walking at 25 metres above ground are all part of the
experience when you traverse the TreeTop Walk, a
250-metre-long freestanding suspension bridge. See
first-hand the layers of the rainforest, from the ground
all the way to the canopy and the emergent layer of
trees, when you take on this scenic seven-kilometre-
long roundtrip to the bridge. From the carpark at Venus
Drive, it's a three- to four-hour hike—do note that the
TreeTop Walk only allows access from one direction.

Southern Ridges. Keep your camera on hand when
you hike the photogenic ten-kilometre-long network of
trails known as the Southern Ridges. The route starts
at HarbourFront Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) station and
takes you three to five hours to walk through Mount
Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill and HortPark before
ending at Kent Ridge Park. Soak in the scenic views

of our skyline and the Southern Islands at the peak of
Mount Faber Park, which is also where you can take
photos with the Merlion sculpture—one of seven that
dot the island. For Instagram-worthy pictures, we
definitely recommend Henderson Waves, the highest

pedestrian bridge in Singapore. The post-modern wood

and steel structure's also an ideal venue for a romantic
night stroll, as it's majestically illuminated by glowing
LED lights from 7pm to 7am.

Relive the footsteps of Malay kings and British
governors at Fort Canning Park. This area used to

be home to Malay royalty, and was also where Sir
Stamford Raffles built his first house, which eventually
became the place of residence for governors. Connect
with history when you explore Fort Canning Service
Reservoir to discover landmarks such as the nine-
pound cannon that dates back to the 19th century;
headstones that mark the site of Singapore's first
Christian cemetery; and Fort Gate, a remnant of the
fortress that was built on this hill.

IN SINGAPO

The golden hour washing over the city's CBD is a

sight to behold. Skyscrapers glimmer and Marina

Bay glistens—it all makes for a postcard-perfect
backdrop for your evening run. The area's proximity

to attractions, restaurants and heritage monuments
also means there's plenty to do and see after this

easy 3.9-kilometre route. Start at the Merlion Park
next to One Fullerton and you'll run past The Fullerton
Heritage precinct, across Marina Bay Sands. You can
cut through the underpass that connects the iconic
towers to Gardens by the Bay and whizz pask lakes and
conservatories before entering the Supertree Grove.
End your run with a last dash towards your final stop,
the Marina Barrage where Singapore's skyline lights up
to celebrate the completion of your run goal.

If there's one place in Singapore that's synonymous
with outdoor revelry, it's East Coast Park, where some
seven million locals and tourists flock to for the variety
of sporting, entertainment and dining attractions. Along
this 15-kiliometre stretch of beach, you'll find hordes
of cyclists and roller bladers enjoying the sun and sea
breeze, while cable skiing and water sports are on offer
for those who prefer wetter pursuits.

Sungai Buloh Wetlands Reserve. Enjoy an up-close
look at mud lobsters, tree-climbing crabs and monitor
lizards when you stroll along the 500-metre-long
boardwalk of the mangrove swamps in Sungei Buloh
Wetland Reserve. The boardwalk runs parallel to the
Wetland Centre. Look to the sky when you head to

the Migratory Bird Trail just a short walk away. From
behind the five hides, two platforms and the 18-metre-
tall Aerie Tower featured along the trail, you can

quietly observe migratory birds such as the Common
Redshank and Pacific Golden Plover that shack up in
this reserve from September to March. Kingfishers,
herons and egrets also visit the reserve regularly.

Bukit Timah is an expansive twist of roads and
buildings, but within the district are tranquil spots for
some quiet. Take
a hike up Bukit
Timah Hill or, for
the adventurous,
go off-tangent and
explore the jungles
of Bukit Timah
Nature Reserve by
mountain bike or
foot.

Punggol is a little far off from the city centre, but you'll
be surprised by the options awaiting you on this end
of the island. Explore the Punggol Waterway Park

by bicycle—there are scores of rental shops around
offering hourly rates—or meander the carved paths of
Coney Island.

710 - SCENIC TRAILS TO RUN OR HIKE IN SINGAPORE /

SCENIC TR

MacRitchie Reservoir Park
Panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of

walking at 25 metres above ground are all part of the
experience when you traverse the TreeTop Walk, a
250-metre-long freestanding suspension bridge. See

singapore_query_019.client_description: are 2 history buffs and museum lovers visiting Singapore for 7 days. They are interested in botanical gardens and wildlife conservation, cultural heritage sites and traditional architecture

singapore_query_020.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 4 art and culture lovers visiting Singapore for 3 days. They are interested in shopping, entertainment, and nightlife, religious sites and spiritual experiences, cultural heritage sites and traditional architecture, ethnic neighborhoods like Chinatown and Little India. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_020.answer:
Day 1: Orchard Road
- Start your day with a visit to the Singapore Visitor Centre on Orchard Road, which offers information on ticketing and reservations.
- Explore the iconic shopping malls, restaurants, and entertainment options on Orchard Road.
- Visit the Singapore Botanic Gardens, the city's first and only UNESCO World Heritage Site and a beautiful garden to stop by.
- Take a detour to Dempsey Hill, one of Singapore's most hip and quaint neighborhoods, for a night's meal with options that include Michelin-starred Candlenut, Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar, The Disgruntled Chef, or go green and experience Open Farm Community's refreshing farm-to-table concept.

Day 2: Tiong Bahru
- Start your day with a visit to the Tiong Bahru Market, which offers a variety of options for a good meal in the morning, such as chwee kueh.
- Explore the hip Tiong Bahru Bakery and enjoy a coffee and a quick bite.
- Visit the independent bookstore BooksActually, which stocks plenty of local titles and retro knick-knacks, and Curated Records, which offers a selection of vinyls, from rare vintage LPs to mainstream hits.
- Take a stroll through the neighborhood and enjoy the charming atmosphere.

Day 3: Little India
- Start your day with a visit to the Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple, which is a visually stunning landmark of the city's many ethnic and religious groups.
- Explore the vibrant streets of Little India, which are a magnet for explorers, and experience the bustling hawker and "wet market" on its ground level with a battalion of rainbow-coloured textile and tailor shops up above.
- Visit the Tekka Centre, which offers a variety of options for a good meal in the morning, such as chwee kueh.
- Take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.

Lighter Day for Recovery:
- Spend the afternoon exploring the streets of Chinatown, which is the oldest housing estate in Singapore, and the vibrant Little India district, which is a cultural vanguard of Singapore.
- Enjoy a leisurely walk through the streets, taking in the sights and sounds, and test your bargaining skills at the Street Market.
- Visit the Nightout @ Chinatown Walking Tour, where the streets come alive! Savour authentic Chinese food and test your bargaining skills at the Street Market. Take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.

1/02 - CONTENTS & A QUICK GUIDE TO SINGAPORE'S DISTRICTS /

A QUICK GUIDE

ORCHARD

Don't just sightsee, be an explorer. Orchard

Road, Asia's most famous shopping street, is

home to fashion favourites, specialist stores
and loads of other lifestyle choices. Today, Orchard
Road is flanked by iconic shopping malls, restaurants
and hotels, choc-a-bloc with retail, dining and enter-
tainment choice for every taste and budget.
The Singapore Visitor Centre is located on Orchard
Road just opposite Orchard Gateway. Discover more
places to explore and get help with ticketing and
reservations. Next to the centre is Emerald Hill Road,

lined with bars and clubs to wind down after a long day

of exploration. The east end of Orchard Road leads to
the Bras Basah and Fort Canning Park while the west
end of the street is just a stone's throw away from the
Singapore Botanic Gardens, the city's first and only

UNESCO World Heritage Site and a beautiful garden to

stop by.

Remember to make a detour to Dempsey Hill, one

of Singapore's most hip and quaint neighbourhoods,
nestled away in lush greenery just minutes from
Orchard Road. Here you'll be spoilt for choice for

the night's meal with options that include Michelin-
starred Candlenut, Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar, The
Disgruntled Chef. Or go green and experience Open
Farm Community's refreshing farm-to-table concept.

TIONG BAHRU

Tiong Bahru is the oldest housing estate

in Singapore, and when you visit this.

quaint community, you'll immediately
notice an intriguing mix of old and new. While many
older residents have lived in the shophouses and flats
here for decades, the younger generation flock here
for the food, shops, and culture. And as food goes,
the choices are abundant. From the sprawling Tiong
Bahru Market with its famous chwee kueh to the
hip Tiong Bahru Bakery, there are plenty of options
for a good meal in the morning. Fancy a coffee
and a quick bite? There are lots of cafés to choose
from — Forty Hands, Flock and cupcakes specialists
Plain Vanilla are just a few of them. It's a great place
to go for a spot of retail therapy, too. Independent
bookstore BooksActually stocks plenty of local
titles and retro knick-knacks, while Curated Records
offers a selection of vinyls, from rare vintage LPs to
mainstream hits.

LITTLE INDIA

Singapore's most colourful district, Little

India's bustling streets are a magnet for

explorers. From rows of shops exuding the
aroma of spices, to fortune-telling tables sprawled
along walkways, the precinct has stood as a cultural
vanguard of Singapore. Tucked away in its roads, you'll
find numerous landmarks of the city's many ethnic
and religious groups including the visually stunning
Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple, Kampong Kapor
Methodist Church, and the colourful expressions of
heritage at the House of Tan Teng Niah. Explore Little
India's heritage trail along its streets and back alleys,
and your eyes will be drawn to extravagant murals
showcasing Singapore's colourful past.

When you're done soaking in the sights and sounds,
to Tekka Centre and experience the bustling hawker
and “wet market” on its ground level with a battalion of
rainbow-coloured textile and tailor shops up above.

- After the tour, visit the local markets such as Chinatown Market and Joo Chiat Market to experience the vibrant and bustling atmosphere.
- In the evening, enjoy a night out at the Chinatown Walking Tour, where you can taste authentic Chinese food and test your bargaining skills.

Day 2: 
- Start the day with a bike tour to explore the quiet streets of Singapore and learn about the historical landmarks and places of interest.
- Visit the National Parks Board to participate in a variety of workshops and guided walks in the parks and gardens.
- In the evening, enjoy a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.

Lighter Day for Recovery:

singapore_query_022.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 3 nature and wildlife enthusiasts visiting Singapore for 5 days. They are interested in religious sites and spiritual experiences, educational experiences and guided tours. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_022.answer:
Day 1: Explore Singapore's cultural heritage and history with a walking tour of Chinatown, followed by a visit to Fort Canning Park. This day will provide a good balance of cultural exploration and historical significance.

Day 2: Take a scenic hike in the Southern Ridges, which offers panoramic views and a chance to connect with history. This day will allow your clients to enjoy the natural beauty of Singapore while also experiencing its rich history.

Day 3: Visit the MacRitchie Reservoir Park for a scenic hike and a chance to see the layers of the rainforest. This day will provide a relaxing and peaceful experience for your clients.

Day 4: Take a guided tour of the Singapore Botanic Gardens, which offers a chance to learn about the city's natural history and enjoy the beautiful gardens. This day will provide an educational experience for your clients.

Day 5: Take a guided tour of the Singapore Zoo, which offers a chance to learn about the city's wildlife and enjoy the beautiful animal exhibits. This day will provide an educational experience for your clients.

Lighter Day: Take a guided tour of the Singapore Botanic Gardens, which offers a chance to learn about the city's natural history and enjoy the beautiful gardens. This day will provide a relaxing and peaceful experience for your clients.

1/10 - SCENIC TRAILS TO RUN OR HIKE IN SINGAPORE /

SCENIC TR

MacRitchie Reservoir Park
Panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of

walking at 25 metres above ground are all part of the
experience when you traverse the TreeTop Walk, a
250-metre-long freestanding suspension bridge. See
first-hand the layers of the rainforest, from the ground
all the way to the canopy and the emergent layer of
trees, when you take on this scenic seven-kilometre-
long roundtrip to the bridge. From the carpark at Venus
Drive, it's a three- to four-hour hike—do note that the
TreeTop Walk only allows access from one direction.

Southern Ridges. Keep your camera on hand when
you hike the photogenic ten-kilometre-long network of
trails known as the Southern Ridges. The route starts
at HarbourFront Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) station and
takes you three to five hours to walk through Mount
Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill and HortPark before
ending at Kent Ridge Park. Soak in the scenic views

of our skyline and the Southern Islands at the peak of
Mount Faber Park, which is also where you can take
photos with the Merlion sculpture—one of seven that
dot the island. For Instagram-worthy pictures, we
definitely recommend Henderson Waves, the highest

pedestrian bridge in Singapore. The post-modern wood

and steel structure's also an ideal venue for a romantic
night stroll, as it's majestically illuminated by glowing
LED lights from 7pm to 7am.

Relive the footsteps of Malay kings and British
governors at Fort Canning Park. This area used to

be home to Malay royalty, and was also where Sir
Stamford Raffles built his first house, which eventually
became the place of residence for governors. Connect
with history when you explore Fort Canning Service
Reservoir to discover landmarks such as the nine-
pound cannon that dates back to the 19th century;
headstones that mark the site of Singapore's first
Christian cemetery; and Fort Gate, a remnant of the
fortress that was built on this hill.

IN SINGAPO

The golden hour washing over the city's CBD is a

sight to behold. Skyscrapers glimmer and Marina

Bay glistens—it all makes for a postcard-perfect
backdrop for your evening run. The area's proximity

to attractions, restaurants and heritage monuments
also means there's plenty to do and see after this

easy 3.9-kilometre route. Start at the Merlion Park
next to One Fullerton and you'll run past The Fullerton
Heritage precinct, across Marina Bay Sands. You can
cut through the underpass that connects the iconic
towers to Gardens by the Bay and whizz pask lakes and
conservatories before entering the Supertree Grove.
End your run with a last dash towards your final stop,
the Marina Barrage where Singapore's skyline lights up
to celebrate the completion of your run goal.

If there's one place in Singapore that's synonymous
with outdoor revelry, it's East Coast Park, where some
seven million locals and tourists flock to for the variety
of sporting, entertainment and dining attractions. Along
this 15-kiliometre stretch of beach, you'll find hordes
of cyclists and roller bladers enjoying the sun and sea
breeze, while cable skiing and water sports are on offer
for those who prefer wetter pursuits.

Sungai Buloh Wetlands Reserve. Enjoy an up-close
look at mud lobsters, tree-climbing crabs and monitor
lizards when you stroll along the 500-metre-long
boardwalk of the mangrove swamps in Sungei Buloh
Wetland Reserve. The boardwalk runs parallel to the
Wetland Centre. Look to the sky when you head to

the Migratory Bird Trail just a short walk away. From
behind the five hides, two platforms and the 18-metre-
tall Aerie Tower featured along the trail, you can

quietly observe migratory birds such as the Common
Redshank and Pacific Golden Plover that shack up in
this reserve from September to March. Kingfishers,
herons and egrets also visit the reserve regularly.

Bukit Timah is an expansive twist of roads and
buildings, but within the district are tranquil spots for
some quiet. Take
a hike up Bukit
Timah Hill or, for
the adventurous,
go off-tangent and
explore the jungles
of Bukit Timah
Nature Reserve by
mountain bike or
foot.

Punggol is a little far off from the city centre, but you'll
be surprised by the options awaiting you on this end
of the island. Explore the Punggol Waterway Park

by bicycle—there are scores of rental shops around
offering hourly rates—or meander the carved paths of
Coney Island.

MEET
SUBARAJ RAJATHURAI

Many of Singapore's nature reserves exist due
" 4 to the efforts of a few individuals like Subaraj
Rajathurai: Self-taught naturalist and veteran

wildlife consultant. Over the last 35 years, he
GARDENS y
BY TH E BAY campaigned peacefully behind the scenes

to preserve some of Singapore's well-loved
ecosystems. In 1987, he and three others drafted
a proposal to save Sungei Buloh, a mangrove

Gardens by the Bay is a quick getaway to some serious greenery, a 101-ha horticultural park with two
conservatories, the Cloud Forest and the Flower Dome. The cool-moist conservatory that is the Cloud Forest
features a 35m-tall mountain covered in plants such as orchids and also sports the world's tallest indoor
waterfall. Meanwhile, the Flower Dome replicates a cool-dry climate and houses plants from the Mediterranean
region and also a Flower Field, where the displays change regularly.

forest in northwest Singapore which was slated
for redevelopment by the government. Thanks
to their perseverance, the wetland was declared
a nature park six years later. In 1992, Subaraj
was also part of the research team responsible
for saving the 123.8 hectares of forest at Lower
Peirce Reservoir.

While tickets are required for entry into the domes, the large three surrounding gardens are open to public to
enjoy. The highlight within the Bay South Garden is the Children's Garden filled with adventure trails for children as
well as the iconic Supertree Grove. The tree-like structures that dominate the Gardens’ landscape that functions
as n environment engine for the gardens and lights up at night with music for a show of its own. Get up close to

the supertrees by exploring the OCBC skyway between the trees —— -
UP y exploring yway / “You can spend five lifetimes exploring nature,

Q 18 Marina Gardens Drive and there would still be more to learn.” says
Subaraj, who fell in love with the rainforest at the
age of 18, during a visit to Bukit Timah Reserve.
Singapore's blend of urban landscapes and
hidden ecosystems keeps him fighting against
rampant urbanisation: “In Singapore, you can
get from a five-star hotel to a rainforest in 20
minutes.”

He believes Singapore is the gateway to Asia, as
much as “it is that gateway for nature."

CHINATOWN
WALKING TOURS

Operated by The Chinatown Association, there's a
walking tour organised on every day of the week
that let you immerse yourself with the underbelly
of Chinatown. Move your senses with the sights
and sounds of hawkers cooking, coffee brewing
and locals bargain-hunting even as you taste
authentic traditional favourites such as Kopi-O,
water cakes and rice rolls in the "Good Morning,
Ni Hao" walking tour!

Explore the traditional customs that surround the
life of the early Chinese immigrant and discover
the reasons behind each practice in the "Passage
of Life: Birth, Marriage & Death” walking tour.

Visit Chinatown at sundown in the Nightout @
Chinatown Walking Tour, where the streets come
alive! Savour authentic Chinese food and test
your bargaining skills at the Street Market. Take a
leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop
onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.

® chinatown.sg

TRISHAW EXPEDITION
BY TRISHAW UNCLE

Say hello to uncle! Trishaw Uncle pays tribute to all
trishaw riders, for providing transport services rain or
shine, from the time before cars, buses and trains.

Embark on a trishaw expedition that takes you through
the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. Expect

a range of sights such as the Rex Cinema and Sri
Veeramakaliamman Temple and learn more about the
various roads such as Selegie Road and Serangoon
Road. Tours are available for Little India, Kampong
Glam, Chinatown as well the Singapore River.

® trishawuncle.com.sg

singapore_query_024.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 6 nature and wildlife enthusiasts visiting Singapore for 6 days. They are interested in luxury experiences and fine dining, traditional crafts and cultural workshops, interactive science exhibits and STEM activities, religious sites and spiritual experiences. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_024.answer:
Day 1: Explore Singapore's natural beauty and wildlife
- Start your day with a scenic hike in MacRitchie Reservoir Park, where you can enjoy panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of walking at 25 metres above ground.
- Take a break at the TreeTop Walk, a 250-metre-long freestanding suspension bridge that allows you to see the layers of the rainforest, from the ground all the way to the canopy and the emergent layer of trees.
- Continue your hike through Mount Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill, and HortPark, and end your day at Kent Ridge Park, where you can take photos with the Merlion sculpture and enjoy the scenic views of the skyline and the Southern Islands at the peak of Mount Faber Park.

Day 2: Relax and enjoy the city's CBD
- Start your day with a scenic run in the CBD, where you can enjoy panoramic views of the city's skyline and Marina Bay glistening.
- Take a break at the Supertree Grove, where you can enjoy the post-modern wood and steel structure's illuminated by glowing LED lights from 7pm to 7am.
- End your day with a visit to the Marina Barrage, where you can celebrate the completion of your run goal and enjoy the skyline lights.

Day 3: Explore Singapore's cultural and historical sites
- Start your day with a visit to Fort Canning Park, where you can relive the footsteps of Malay kings and British governors.
- Take a break at the Fort Canning Service Reservoir, where you can discover landmarks such as the nine-pound cannon that dates back to the 19th century, headstones that mark the site of Singapore's first Christian cemetery, and Fort Gate, a remnant of the fortress that was built on this hill.
- End your day with a visit to the Singapore Botanic Gardens, where you can enjoy the beautiful gardens and learn about the city's rich history and culture.

Day 4: Enjoy the city's fine dining and luxury experiences
- Start your day with a visit to one of Singapore's top restaurants, where you can enjoy a luxurious meal and learn about the city's culinary traditions.
- Take a break at the Singapore Art Museum, where you can learn about the city's rich history and culture through interactive science exhibits and STEM activities.
- End your day with a visit to a traditional crafts and cultural workshop, where you can learn about the city's rich history and culture through interactive science exhibits and STEM activities.

Day 5: Explore Singapore's natural beauty and wildlife
- Start your day with a scenic hike in Bukit Timah Hill, where you can enjoy tranquil spots for some quiet.
- Take a break at the Bukit Timah Nature Reserve, where you can explore the jungles and enjoy an up-close look at mud lobsters, tree-climbing crabs, and monitor lizards.
- End your day with a visit to the Singapore Zoo, where you can enjoy the city's rich history and culture through interactive science exhibits and STEM activities.

Day 6: Relax and enjoy the city's CBD
- Start your day with a scenic run in the CBD, where you can enjoy panoramic views of the city's skyline and Marina Bay glistening.
- Take a break at the Supertree Grove, where you can enjoy the post-modern wood and steel structure's illuminated by glowing LED lights from 7pm to 7am.
- End your day with a visit to the Marina Barrage, where you can celebrate the completion of your run goal and enjoy the skyline lights.

Lighter Day for Recovery: Day 7
- Start your day with a visit to a local market, where you can enjoy the city's rich history and culture through interactive science exhibits and STEM activities.
- Take a break at the Singapore Botanic Gardens, where you can enjoy the beautiful gardens and learn about the city's rich history and culture.
- End your day with a visit to a traditional crafts and cultural workshop, where you can learn about the city's rich history and culture through interactive science exhibits and STEM activities.

1/10 - SCENIC TRAILS TO RUN OR HIKE IN SINGAPORE /

SCENIC TR

MacRitchie Reservoir Park
Panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of

walking at 25 metres above ground are all part of the
experience when you traverse the TreeTop Walk, a
250-metre-long freestanding suspension bridge. See
first-hand the layers of the rainforest, from the ground
all the way to the canopy and the emergent layer of
trees, when you take on this scenic seven-kilometre-
long roundtrip to the bridge. From the carpark at Venus
Drive, it's a three- to four-hour hike—do note that the
TreeTop Walk only allows access from one direction.

Southern Ridges. Keep your camera on hand when
you hike the photogenic ten-kilometre-long network of
trails known as the Southern Ridges. The route starts
at HarbourFront Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) station and
takes you three to five hours to walk through Mount
Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill and HortPark before
ending at Kent Ridge Park. Soak in the scenic views

of our skyline and the Southern Islands at the peak of
Mount Faber Park, which is also where you can take
photos with the Merlion sculpture—one of seven that
dot the island. For Instagram-worthy pictures, we
definitely recommend Henderson Waves, the highest

pedestrian bridge in Singapore. The post-modern wood

and steel structure's also an ideal venue for a romantic
night stroll, as it's majestically illuminated by glowing
LED lights from 7pm to 7am.

Relive the footsteps of Malay kings and British
governors at Fort Canning Park. This area used to

be home to Malay royalty, and was also where Sir
Stamford Raffles built his first house, which eventually
became the place of residence for governors. Connect
with history when you explore Fort Canning Service
Reservoir to discover landmarks such as the nine-
pound cannon that dates back to the 19th century;
headstones that mark the site of Singapore's first
Christian cemetery; and Fort Gate, a remnant of the
fortress that was built on this hill.

IN SINGAPO

The golden hour washing over the city's CBD is a

sight to behold. Skyscrapers glimmer and Marina

Bay glistens—it all makes for a postcard-perfect
backdrop for your evening run. The area's proximity

to attractions, restaurants and heritage monuments
also means there's plenty to do and see after this

easy 3.9-kilometre route. Start at the Merlion Park
next to One Fullerton and you'll run past The Fullerton
Heritage precinct, across Marina Bay Sands. You can
cut through the underpass that connects the iconic
towers to Gardens by the Bay and whizz pask lakes and
conservatories before entering the Supertree Grove.
End your run with a last dash towards your final stop,
the Marina Barrage where Singapore's skyline lights up
to celebrate the completion of your run goal.

If there's one place in Singapore that's synonymous
with outdoor revelry, it's East Coast Park, where some
seven million locals and tourists flock to for the variety
of sporting, entertainment and dining attractions. Along
this 15-kiliometre stretch of beach, you'll find hordes
of cyclists and roller bladers enjoying the sun and sea
breeze, while cable skiing and water sports are on offer
for those who prefer wetter pursuits.

Sungai Buloh Wetlands Reserve. Enjoy an up-close
look at mud lobsters, tree-climbing crabs and monitor
lizards when you stroll along the 500-metre-long

Wetland Centre. Look to the sky when you head to

behind the five hides, two platforms and the 18-metre-
tall Aerie Tower featured along the trail, you can

quietly observe migratory birds such as the Common
Redshank and Pacific Golden Plover that shack up in
this reserve from September to March. Kingfishers,
herons and egrets also visit the reserve regularly.

Bukit Timah is an expansive twist of roads and
buildings, but within the district are tranquil spots for
some quiet. Take
a hike up Bukit
Timah Hill or, for
the adventurous,
go off-tangent and
explore the jungles
of Bukit Timah
Nature Reserve by
mountain bike or
foot.

Punggol is a little far off from the city centre, but you'll
be surprised by the options awaiting you on this end
of the island. Explore the Punggol Waterway Park

by bicycle—there are scores of rental shops around
offering hourly rates—or meander the carved paths of
Coney Island.

walking tour organised on every day of the week
that let you immerse yourself with the underbelly
of Chinatown. Move your senses with the sights
and sounds of hawkers cooking, coffee brewing
and locals bargain-hunting even as you taste
authentic traditional favourites such as Kopi-O,
water cakes and rice rolls in the "Good Morning,
Ni Hao" walking tour!

Explore the traditional customs that surround the
life of the early Chinese immigrant and discover
the reasons behind each practice in the "Passage
of Life: Birth, Marriage & Death” walking tour.

Visit Chinatown at sundown in the Nightout @
Chinatown Walking Tour, where the streets come
alive! Savour authentic Chinese food and test
your bargaining skills at the Street Market. Take a
leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop
onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.

® chinatown.sg

TRISHAW EXPEDITION
BY TRISHAW UNCLE

Say hello to uncle! Trishaw Uncle pays tribute to all
trishaw riders, for providing transport services rain or
shine, from the time before cars, buses and trains.

Embark on a trishaw expedition that takes you through
the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. Expect

a range of sights such as the Rex Cinema and Sri
Veeramakaliamman Temple and learn more about the
various roads such as Selegie Road and Serangoon
Road. Tours are available for Little India, Kampong
Glam, Chinatown as well the Singapore River.

® trishawuncle.com.sg
