singapore_query_025.client_description: are a family of 3 with children aged 3 and 8 visiting Singapore for 3 days. They are interested in maritime history and waterfront attractions, modern art galleries and contemporary culture

singapore_query_026.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 6 art and culture lovers visiting Singapore for 5 days. They are interested in cultural heritage sites and traditional architecture, family-friendly attractions and theme parks. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_026.answer:
Day 1: Explore the Civic District and Fort Canning Park
Day 2: Visit the National Gallery Singapore and the Asian Civilizations Museum
Day 3: Explore the Colonial District and Fort Canning Park
Day 4: Visit the National Parks Board and the Singapore River
Day 5: Relax and enjoy a light meal at a local restaurant
Lighter Day: Take a Vespa tour through Chinatown and Joo Chiat
Note: This itinerary is based on the information provided in the context and may not be suitable for all clients. It is recommended to consult with a local travel agent or a travel guide for a more personalized itinerary.

contexts.text:
KAMPONG
GLAM

Some say Kampong Glam really is glam
(a local term meaning ‘glamorous’). The area has
an eclectic blend of history, culture and a super-
trendy lifestyle scene. Start from the landmark Sultan
Mosque, and wander through the many side streets.
The grounds of the former ‘Istana’ (‘palace’) to Sultan
Hussain Mohammed Shah is home to the Malay

103 - A QUICK GUIDE TO SINGAPORE’S DISTRICTS /

history and culture better. Wander the streets and you'll
soon uncover Haji Lane, a row of multi-label stores,
quirky boutiques as well as hip bars and cafes. Or pick
up traditional wares such as Persian carpets, kebaya
dresses and handmade perfumes from Arab Street and
Bussorah Street. The nasi padang (Indonesian dishes
flavoured with spices and served with rice) at Hjh
Maimunah is famous among locals. Café and boutique
Maison Ikkoku on Kandahar Street offers tasty
modern grub, and also houses an excellent rooftop

Heritage Centre, where you can get to know Malay cocktail bar.

JALAN BESAR,
ROCHER,
LAVENDER

Now a conserved area, Jalan Besar is home
to an eclectic range of eateries, cafés, entertainment
venues, and religious sites. It's also a hostel hotspot,
and backpackers constantly flock here. Beyond the
neon lights of bars and lounges, Jalan Besar is rife with
hip cafés that are now calling the neighbourhood's
many shophouses home. You can easily spend an
entire afternoon hopping from one spot to another
such as Chye Seng Huat Hardware, all while tucking
into hearty brunch plates, classic French pastries and
modern takes on local cuisine such as Non Entrée
Desserts. The district is also making a name for itself
as a haven for Third Wave coffee, so you will have
plenty of fuel for your trip.

THE CIVIC
DISTRICT

The Civic District is where Singapore's
historical, architectural and cultural heritage started.
Located right at the mouth of the Singapore River, the
Civic District is at the heart of the city's past, with key
landmarks from prominent historical figures such as Sir
Stamford Raffles, the man who founded Singapore, to
up-and-coming architectural icons of the 21st century.
Among key historical landmarks include St Andrew's
Cathedral, National Gallery Singapore which comprises
the historical Supreme Court and City Hall, Padang,
the Asian Civilisations Museum, The Arts House (Old
Parliament House) and Victoria Theatre, overlooking the
magnificent Fullerton Hotel and Esplanade - Theatres
on the Bay which locals affectionately call "the durian”.

BRAS BASAH BUGIS

Bras Basah.Bugis Precinct is where to go for a slice of Singapore's rich heritage, preserved

architecture and palpable energy. Head here for fine museums, national monuments and other

institutions, such as art schools and the Central Public Library. One of Singapore's oldest districts,
Bras Basah derived its name from the Malay term for ‘wet rice’ and Sir Stamford Raffles picked the area to be
the European center of Singapore Town. The adjacent Bugis Street, named after the seafaring Bugis people
from Indonesia who came here to trade with local merchants, has a less pristine past. You could spend days
just soaking in the vibe of this buzzing district. The district is home to museums such as the National Museum
of Singapore, The Singapore Art Museum and Peranakan Museum, and national monuments like the Armenian
Church and Central Fire Station, Singapore's oldest fire station. Explore CHIJMES, an enclave of restaurants and
bars in the middle of the city. The former chapel and school with its green lawns, marble waterfalls, courtyards
and neoclassical buildings — harks back to a bygone, more gracious age. A thriving district with a colourful past,
it now boasts everything shoppers could ever ask for; malls such as Bugis+ and Bugis Junction, charming
boutiques, bustling street markets, and of course, bargains at every corner.

THE COLONIAL
DISTRICT

Singapore's Colonial District is peppered with
reminders of British colonial rule. Together with Bras Basah
Bugis district and adjoining into the Civic District, it's the
centerpiece of Singapore surrounded by more modern
trappings that rise up around it. The district is anchored
by Fort Canning Park, an iconic hilltop landmark that has
witnessed many of Singapore's historical milestones. The
hill once sited the palaces of 14th century Malay Kings and
served as the Headquarters of the Far East Command Centre and British Army Barracks. Today, Fort Canning Park
is a venue for celebrations. Its expansive, sprawling lawns play host to concerts, theatre productions and festivals
such as Shakespeare in the Park, Ballet Under the Stars, and Films at the Fort, while weddings, parties and
gatherings are a regular sight in the park's venue spaces. Its ancient artefacts are a must-see for history buffs, and
its lush greenery and expansive lawns offer a variety of arts, heritage and nature experiences. Down the hill, you
can trace Singapore's history through stamps at the Singapore Philatelic Museum before stopping for lunch at the
Raffles Hotel. Raffles Hotel was the crown of colonial indulgence with a reputation of luxury. It is at this hotel's bar
where the legendary Singapore Sling was created

} THE QUAYS
ON SINGAPORE
RIVER

Consisting of a trio of Clarke Quay,
Robertson Quay and Boat Quay, you can literally
walk from the mouth of Singapore River through the
river valleys along some of the most pristine walking
paths. Shophouses along Boat Quay that used to
be the centre of trade has now been conserved and
adapted for modern use, offering up various bars,
‘ pubs and restaurants. Warehouses along Clarke
Quay are today Iconic dance clubs and live music
venues, rooftop bars, creating trendy nightspots for heart-pumping entertainment. Together, both Clarke Quay and
Boat Quay is a must-have stop for the city's most lively nightlife spots. As you move further inwards, Robertson Quay
offers a more quiet respite, with locals often seen running along its banks. The area combines upperclass residential
apartments with designer hotels such as M Social and The Warehouse Hotel with wonderful choices of gastronomic
options that would satisfy any foodie.

KAMPONG
GLAM

Some say Kampong Glam really is glam
(a local term meaning ‘glamorous’. The area has
an eclectic blend of history, culture and a super-
trendy lifestyle scene. Start from the landmark Sultan
Mosque, and wander through the many side streets.
The grounds of the former ‘Istana’ (‘palace’) to Sultan
Hussain Mohammed Shah is home to the Malay

Dubbed the world's first vintage Vespa sidecar
tour service, jump into one of these charming
sidecars for an unforgettable tour. Explore the
heritage lanes of Chinatown and Joo Chiat, go on
a food and pub trail or view Singapore through a
photographer's lens.

) LET’S GO! NATIONAL
, BIKE SINGAPORE PARKS BOARD

The best way to know Singapore? Are you looking to bring your children out for a
On a bicycle! Ride on sidewalks and meaningful learning journey through Singapore's
quiet little streets that no bus tour can parks and gardens? The National Parks Board
get to. Meander along the Singapore organises a variety of different workshops and
River to see historical landmarks, guided walks in the various parks and gardens
museums and places of interest with the aim of creating a living learning

Pause at Singaporeans’ favourite environment that would enrich children. These
hangout: our humble ‘coffeeshop' to include activities around Central Nature Reserve,
try local drinks and snacks. Learn how Pulau Ubin, Fort Canning Park, The Southern
Singapore transformed from a sleepy Ridges and the Botanic Gardens.

village into the metropolis it is today. © nparks.govsg

‘4 @ letsgobikesingapore.com

CHINATOWN
WALKING TOURS

Operated by The Chinatown Association, there's a
walking tour organised on every day of the week
that let you immerse yourself with the underbelly
of Chinatown. Move your senses with the sights
and sounds of hawkers cooking, coffee brewing
and locals bargain-hunting even as you taste
authentic traditional favourites such as Kopi-O,
water cakes and rice rolls in the "Good Morning,
Ni Hao" walking tour!

Explore the traditional customs that surround the
life of the early Chinese immigrant and discover
the reasons behind each practice in the "Passage
of Life: Birth, Marriage & Death” walking tour.

Visit Chinatown at sundown in the Nightout @
Chinatown Walking Tour, where the streets come
alive! Savour authentic Chinese food and test
your bargaining skills at the Street Market. Take a
leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop
onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.

® chinatown.sg

TRISHAW EXPEDITION
BY TRISHAW UNCLE

Say hello to uncle! Trishaw Uncle pays tribute to all
trishaw riders, for providing transport services rain or
shine, from the time before cars, buses and trains.

Embark on a trishaw expedition that takes you through
the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. Expect

a range of sights such as the Rex Cinema and Sri
Veeramakaliamman Temple and learn more about the
various roads such as Selegie Road and Serangoon
Road. Tours are available for Little India, Kampong
Glam, Chinatown as well the Singapore River.

® trishawuncle.com.sg

singapore_query_028.answer:
Day 1: Arrival in Singapore

Day 3: Religious Sites and Cultural Exploration

- Evening: Trishaw Expedition tour through Singapore's vibrant streets

Day 4: Light Day for Recovery
- Morning: Visit the Singapore River and Clarke Quay

- Evening: Light dinner at a local café
- Light walk or leisurely bike ride around the Singapore Botanic Gardens

Day 5: Departure
- Check-out of the hotel
- Transfer to the airport

1/02 - CONTENTS & A QUICK GUIDE TO SINGAPORE'S DISTRICTS /

A QUICK GUIDE

ORCHARD

Don't just sightsee, be an explorer. Orchard

Road, Asia's most famous shopping street, is

home to fashion favourites, specialist stores
and loads of other lifestyle choices. Today, Orchard
Road is flanked by iconic shopping malls, restaurants
and hotels, choc-a-bloc with retail, dining and enter-
tainment choice for every taste and budget.
The Singapore Visitor Centre is located on Orchard
Road just opposite Orchard Gateway. Discover more
places to explore and get help with ticketing and
reservations. Next to the centre is Emerald Hill Road,

lined with bars and clubs to wind down after a long day

of exploration. The east end of Orchard Road leads to
the Bras Basah and Fort Canning Park while the west
end of the street is just a stone's throw away from the
Singapore Botanic Gardens, the city's first and only

UNESCO World Heritage Site and a beautiful garden to

stop by.

Remember to make a detour to Dempsey Hill, one

of Singapore's most hip and quaint neighbourhoods,
nestled away in lush greenery just minutes from
Orchard Road. Here you'll be spoilt for choice for

the night's meal with options that include Michelin-
starred Candlenut, Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar, The
Disgruntled Chef. Or go green and experience Open
Farm Community's refreshing farm-to-table concept.

TIONG BAHRU

Tiong Bahru is the oldest housing estate

in Singapore, and when you visit this.

quaint community, you'll immediately
notice an intriguing mix of old and new. While many
older residents have lived in the shophouses and flats
here for decades, the younger generation flock here
for the food, shops, and culture. And as food goes,
the choices are abundant. From the sprawling Tiong
Bahru Market with its famous chwee kueh to the
hip Tiong Bahru Bakery, there are plenty of options
for a good meal in the morning. Fancy a coffee
and a quick bite? There are lots of cafés to choose
from — Forty Hands, Flock and cupcakes specialists
Plain Vanilla are just a few of them. It's a great place
to go for a spot of retail therapy, too. Independent
bookstore BooksActually stocks plenty of local
titles and retro knick-knacks, while Curated Records
offers a selection of vinyls, from rare vintage LPs to
mainstream hits.

LITTLE INDIA

Singapore's most colourful district, Little

India's bustling streets are a magnet for

explorers. From rows of shops exuding the
aroma of spices, to fortune-telling tables sprawled
along walkways, the precinct has stood as a cultural
vanguard of Singapore. Tucked away in its roads, you'll
find numerous landmarks of the city's many ethnic
and religious groups including the visually stunning
Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple, Kampong Kapor
Methodist Church, and the colourful expressions of
heritage at the House of Tan Teng Niah. Explore Little
India's heritage trail along its streets and back alleys,
and your eyes will be drawn to extravagant murals
showcasing Singapore's colourful past.

When you're done soaking in the sights and sounds,
to Tekka Centre and experience the bustling hawker
and “wet market” on its ground level with a battalion of
rainbow-coloured textile and tailor shops up above.

singapore_query_030.client_description: are 2 business colleagues visiting Singapore for 5 days. They are interested in wellness activities and relaxation, traditional crafts and cultural workshops, family-friendly attractions and theme parks

singapore_query_031.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 3 adventure seekers visiting Singapore for 4 days. They are interested in ethnic neighborhoods like Chinatown and Little India, traditional crafts and cultural workshops. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_031.answer:
Day 1: Explore Chinatown and Little India
- Start your adventure in Chinatown, where you can immerse yourself in the vibrant atmosphere and try authentic traditional favorites like Kopi-O, water cakes, and rice rolls.
- Visit the "Good Morning, Ni Hao" walking tour to explore the sights and sounds of the neighborhood.
- Take a leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.
- In the evening, enjoy authentic Chinese food and test your bargaining skills at the Street Market.
- Visit the "Passage of Life: Birth, Marriage & Death" walking tour to learn about the traditional customs surrounding the life of the early Chinese immigrant.
- End your day with a night out at Chinatown, where the streets come alive!

Day 2: Traditional Crafts and Cultural Workshops
- Start your day with a visit to the National Parks Board's workshops and guided walks in the various parks and gardens.
- Take a guided tour of the Singapore Botanic Gardens, the city's first and only UNESCO World Heritage Site and a beautiful garden to stop by.
- Visit Dempsey Hill, one of Singapore's most hip and quaint neighborhoods, and enjoy Michelin-starred cuisine at Candlenut, Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar, or The Disgruntled Chef.
- Experience Open Farm Community's refreshing farm-to-table concept and enjoy a meal with a view.
- In the evening, attend a traditional craft workshop or cultural workshop at a local community center or cultural center.

Day 3: Lighter Day for Recovery
- Start your day with a visit to Tiong Bahru, the oldest housing estate in Singapore, and enjoy a meal at a local café or bakery.
- Visit the Tiong Bahru Market and try the famous chwee kueh.
- Take a stroll through the streets of Little India and explore the vibrant atmosphere and cultural landmarks.
- Visit the Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple and the colourful expressions of heritage at the House of Tan Teng Niah.
- End your day with a relaxing walk along the Singapore River and enjoy a leisurely trishaw ride.

Day 4: Final Exploration and Departure
- Start your day with a visit to the Singapore Visitor Centre and discover more places to explore and get help with ticketing and reservations.
- Take a guided tour of the Singapore Botanic Gardens and learn more about the various roads such as Selegie Road and Serangoon Road.
- Visit the Singapore River and enjoy a leisurely trishaw ride.
- End your day with a farewell dinner at a local restaurant or café and say goodbye to Singapore.

1/02 - CONTENTS & A QUICK GUIDE TO SINGAPORE'S DISTRICTS /

A QUICK GUIDE

ORCHARD

Don't just sightsee, be an explorer. Orchard

Road, Asia's most famous shopping street, is

home to fashion favourites, specialist stores
and loads of other lifestyle choices. Today, Orchard
Road is flanked by iconic shopping malls, restaurants
and hotels, choc-a-bloc with retail, dining and enter-
tainment choice for every taste and budget.
The Singapore Visitor Centre is located on Orchard
Road just opposite Orchard Gateway. Discover more
places to explore and get help with ticketing and
reservations. Next to the centre is Emerald Hill Road,

lined with bars and clubs to wind down after a long day

of exploration. The east end of Orchard Road leads to
the Bras Basah and Fort Canning Park while the west
end of the street is just a stone's throw away from the
Singapore Botanic Gardens, the city's first and only

UNESCO World Heritage Site and a beautiful garden to

stop by.

Remember to make a detour to Dempsey Hill, one

of Singapore's most hip and quaint neighbourhoods,
nestled away in lush greenery just minutes from
Orchard Road. Here you'll be spoilt for choice for

the night's meal with options that include Michelin-
starred Candlenut, Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar, The
Disgruntled Chef. Or go green and experience Open
Farm Community's refreshing farm-to-table concept.

TIONG BAHRU

Tiong Bahru is the oldest housing estate

in Singapore, and when you visit this.

quaint community, you'll immediately
notice an intriguing mix of old and new. While many
older residents have lived in the shophouses and flats
here for decades, the younger generation flock here
for the food, shops, and culture. And as food goes,
the choices are abundant. From the sprawling Tiong
Bahru Market with its famous chwee kueh to the
hip Tiong Bahru Bakery, there are plenty of options
for a good meal in the morning. Fancy a coffee
and a quick bite? There are lots of cafés to choose
from — Forty Hands, Flock and cupcakes specialists
Plain Vanilla are just a few of them. It's a great place
to go for a spot of retail therapy, too. Independent
bookstore BooksActually stocks plenty of local
titles and retro knick-knacks, while Curated Records
offers a selection of vinyls, from rare vintage LPs to
mainstream hits.

LITTLE INDIA

Singapore's most colourful district, Little

India's bustling streets are a magnet for

explorers. From rows of shops exuding the
aroma of spices, to fortune-telling tables sprawled
along walkways, the precinct has stood as a cultural
vanguard of Singapore. Tucked away in its roads, you'll
find numerous landmarks of the city's many ethnic
and religious groups including the visually stunning
Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple, Kampong Kapor
Methodist Church, and the colourful expressions of
heritage at the House of Tan Teng Niah. Explore Little
India's heritage trail along its streets and back alleys,
and your eyes will be drawn to extravagant murals
showcasing Singapore's colourful past.

When you're done soaking in the sights and sounds,
to Tekka Centre and experience the bustling hawker
and “wet market” on its ground level with a battalion of
rainbow-coloured textile and tailor shops up above.

Day 2: Visit the Singapore Zoo and the Singapore Science Centre. Spend the day learning about the local wildlife and participating in interactive science exhibits. In the evening, enjoy a light dinner at a local restaurant.

Day 3: Visit the Singapore Botanic Gardens and the Singapore Botanic Gardens. Spend the day exploring the gardens and learning about the local flora and fauna. In the evening, enjoy a light dinner at a local restaurant.

/ 08 - LITTLE EXPLORERS: BEING WITH MOTHER NATURE /

MEET
SUBARAJ RAJATHURAI

Many of Singapore's nature reserves exist due
" 4 to the efforts of a few individuals like Subaraj
Rajathurai: Self-taught naturalist and veteran

wildlife consultant. Over the last 35 years, he
GARDENS y
BY TH E BAY campaigned peacefully behind the scenes

to preserve some of Singapore's well-loved
ecosystems. In 1987, he and three others drafted
a proposal to save Sungei Buloh, a mangrove

Gardens by the Bay is a quick getaway to some serious greenery, a 101-ha horticultural park with two
conservatories, the Cloud Forest and the Flower Dome. The cool-moist conservatory that is the Cloud Forest
features a 35m-tall mountain covered in plants such as orchids and also sports the world's tallest indoor
waterfall. Meanwhile, the Flower Dome replicates a cool-dry climate and houses plants from the Mediterranean
region and also a Flower Field, where the displays change regularly.

forest in northwest Singapore which was slated
for redevelopment by the government. Thanks
to their perseverance, the wetland was declared
a nature park six years later. In 1992, Subaraj
was also part of the research team responsible
for saving the 123.8 hectares of forest at Lower
Peirce Reservoir.

While tickets are required for entry into the domes, the large three surrounding gardens are open to public to
enjoy. The highlight within the Bay South Garden is the Children's Garden filled with adventure trails for children as
well as the iconic Supertree Grove. The tree-like structures that dominate the Gardens’ landscape that functions
as n environment engine for the gardens and lights up at night with music for a show of its own. Get up close to

the supertrees by exploring the OCBC skyway between the trees —— -
UP y exploring yway / “You can spend five lifetimes exploring nature,

Q 18 Marina Gardens Drive and there would still be more to learn.” says
Subaraj, who fell in love with the rainforest at the
age of 18, during a visit to Bukit Timah Reserve.
Singapore's blend of urban landscapes and
hidden ecosystems keeps him fighting against
rampant urbanisation: “In Singapore, you can
get from a five-star hotel to a rainforest in 20
minutes.”

He believes Singapore is the gateway to Asia, as
much as “it is that gateway for nature."

See Singapore through the eyes of a nature lover:
www.visitsingapore.com/en_my/see-do-singapore/
explorers/subaraj-rajathurai.html

from Changi Point Ferry Terminal, 51 Lor Bekukong

9 1 Cluny Road

1/10 - SCENIC TRAILS TO RUN OR HIKE IN SINGAPORE /

SCENIC TR

MacRitchie Reservoir Park
Panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of

walking at 25 metres above ground are all part of the
experience when you traverse the TreeTop Walk, a
250-metre-long freestanding suspension bridge. See
first-hand the layers of the rainforest, from the ground
all the way to the canopy and the emergent layer of
trees, when you take on this scenic seven-kilometre-
long roundtrip to the bridge. From the carpark at Venus
Drive, it's a three- to four-hour hike—do note that the
TreeTop Walk only allows access from one direction.

Southern Ridges. Keep your camera on hand when
you hike the photogenic ten-kilometre-long network of
trails known as the Southern Ridges. The route starts
at HarbourFront Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) station and
takes you three to five hours to walk through Mount
Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill and HortPark before
ending at Kent Ridge Park. Soak in the scenic views

of our skyline and the Southern Islands at the peak of
Mount Faber Park, which is also where you can take
photos with the Merlion sculpture—one of seven that
dot the island. For Instagram-worthy pictures, we
definitely recommend Henderson Waves, the highest

pedestrian bridge in Singapore. The post-modern wood

and steel structure's also an ideal venue for a romantic
night stroll, as it's majestically illuminated by glowing
LED lights from 7pm to 7am.

Relive the footsteps of Malay kings and British
governors at Fort Canning Park. This area used to

be home to Malay royalty, and was also where Sir
Stamford Raffles built his first house, which eventually
became the place of residence for governors. Connect
with history when you explore Fort Canning Service
Reservoir to discover landmarks such as the nine-
pound cannon that dates back to the 19th century;
headstones that mark the site of Singapore's first
Christian cemetery; and Fort Gate, a remnant of the
fortress that was built on this hill.

IN SINGAPO

The golden hour washing over the city's CBD is a

sight to behold. Skyscrapers glimmer and Marina

Bay glistens—it all makes for a postcard-perfect
backdrop for your evening run. The area's proximity

to attractions, restaurants and heritage monuments
also means there's plenty to do and see after this

easy 3.9-kilometre route. Start at the Merlion Park
next to One Fullerton and you'll run past The Fullerton
Heritage precinct, across Marina Bay Sands. You can
cut through the underpass that connects the iconic
towers to Gardens by the Bay and whizz pask lakes and
conservatories before entering the Supertree Grove.
End your run with a last dash towards your final stop,
the Marina Barrage where Singapore's skyline lights up
to celebrate the completion of your run goal.

If there's one place in Singapore that's synonymous
with outdoor revelry, it's East Coast Park, where some
seven million locals and tourists flock to for the variety
of sporting, entertainment and dining attractions. Along
this 15-kiliometre stretch of beach, you'll find hordes
of cyclists and roller bladers enjoying the sun and sea
breeze, while cable skiing and water sports are on offer
for those who prefer wetter pursuits.

Sungai Buloh Wetlands Reserve. Enjoy an up-close
look at mud lobsters, tree-climbing crabs and monitor
lizards when you stroll along the 500-metre-long
boardwalk of the mangrove swamps in Sungei Buloh
Wetland Reserve. The boardwalk runs parallel to the
Wetland Centre. Look to the sky when you head to

the Migratory Bird Trail just a short walk away. From
behind the five hides, two platforms and the 18-metre-
tall Aerie Tower featured along the trail, you can

quietly observe migratory birds such as the Common
Redshank and Pacific Golden Plover that shack up in
this reserve from September to March. Kingfishers,
herons and egrets also visit the reserve regularly.

Bukit Timah is an expansive twist of roads and
buildings, but within the district are tranquil spots for
some quiet. Take
a hike up Bukit
Timah Hill or, for
the adventurous,
go off-tangent and
explore the jungles
of Bukit Timah
Nature Reserve by
mountain bike or
foot.

Punggol is a little far off from the city centre, but you'll
be surprised by the options awaiting you on this end
of the island. Explore the Punggol Waterway Park

by bicycle—there are scores of rental shops around
offering hourly rates—or meander the carved paths of
Coney Island.

contexts.text:
KAMPONG
GLAM

Some say Kampong Glam really is glam
(a local term meaning ‘glamorous’). The area has
an eclectic blend of history, culture and a super-
trendy lifestyle scene. Start from the landmark Sultan
Mosque, and wander through the many side streets.
The grounds of the former ‘Istana’ (‘palace’) to Sultan
Hussain Mohammed Shah is home to the Malay

103 - A QUICK GUIDE TO SINGAPORE’S DISTRICTS /

history and culture better. Wander the streets and you'll
soon uncover Haji Lane, a row of multi-label stores,
quirky boutiques as well as hip bars and cafes. Or pick
up traditional wares such as Persian carpets, kebaya
dresses and handmade perfumes from Arab Street and
Bussorah Street. The nasi padang (Indonesian dishes
flavoured with spices and served with rice) at Hjh
Maimunah is famous among locals. Café and boutique
Maison Ikkoku on Kandahar Street offers tasty
modern grub, and also houses an excellent rooftop

Heritage Centre, where you can get to know Malay cocktail bar.

JALAN BESAR,
ROCHER,
LAVENDER

Now a conserved area, Jalan Besar is home
to an eclectic range of eateries, cafés, entertainment
venues, and religious sites. It's also a hostel hotspot,
and backpackers constantly flock here. Beyond the
neon lights of bars and lounges, Jalan Besar is rife with
hip cafés that are now calling the neighbourhood's
many shophouses home. You can easily spend an
entire afternoon hopping from one spot to another
such as Chye Seng Huat Hardware, all while tucking
into hearty brunch plates, classic French pastries and
modern takes on local cuisine such as Non Entrée
Desserts. The district is also making a name for itself
as a haven for Third Wave coffee, so you will have
plenty of fuel for your trip.

THE CIVIC
DISTRICT

The Civic District is where Singapore's
historical, architectural and cultural heritage started.
Located right at the mouth of the Singapore River, the
Civic District is at the heart of the city's past, with key
landmarks from prominent historical figures such as Sir
Stamford Raffles, the man who founded Singapore, to
up-and-coming architectural icons of the 21st century.
Among key historical landmarks include St Andrew's
Cathedral, National Gallery Singapore which comprises
the historical Supreme Court and City Hall, Padang,
the Asian Civilisations Museum, The Arts House (Old
Parliament House) and Victoria Theatre, overlooking the
magnificent Fullerton Hotel and Esplanade - Theatres
on the Bay which locals affectionately call "the durian”.

BRAS BASAH BUGIS

Bras Basah.Bugis Precinct is where to go for a slice of Singapore's rich heritage, preserved

architecture and palpable energy. Head here for fine museums, national monuments and other

institutions, such as art schools and the Central Public Library. One of Singapore's oldest districts,
Bras Basah derived its name from the Malay term for ‘wet rice’ and Sir Stamford Raffles picked the area to be
the European center of Singapore Town. The adjacent Bugis Street, named after the seafaring Bugis people
from Indonesia who came here to trade with local merchants, has a less pristine past. You could spend days
just soaking in the vibe of this buzzing district. The district is home to museums such as the National Museum
of Singapore, The Singapore Art Museum and Peranakan Museum, and national monuments like the Armenian
Church and Central Fire Station, Singapore's oldest fire station. Explore CHIJMES, an enclave of restaurants and
bars in the middle of the city. The former chapel and school with its green lawns, marble waterfalls, courtyards
and neoclassical buildings — harks back to a bygone, more gracious age. A thriving district with a colourful past,
it now boasts everything shoppers could ever ask for; malls such as Bugis+ and Bugis Junction, charming
boutiques, bustling street markets, and of course, bargains at every corner.

THE COLONIAL
DISTRICT

Singapore's Colonial District is peppered with
reminders of British colonial rule. Together with Bras Basah
Bugis district and adjoining into the Civic District, it's the
centerpiece of Singapore surrounded by more modern
trappings that rise up around it. The district is anchored
by Fort Canning Park, an iconic hilltop landmark that has
witnessed many of Singapore's historical milestones. The
hill once sited the palaces of 14th century Malay Kings and
served as the Headquarters of the Far East Command Centre and British Army Barracks. Today, Fort Canning Park
is a venue for celebrations. Its expansive, sprawling lawns play host to concerts, theatre productions and festivals
such as Shakespeare in the Park, Ballet Under the Stars, and Films at the Fort, while weddings, parties and
gatherings are a regular sight in the park's venue spaces. Its ancient artefacts are a must-see for history buffs, and
its lush greenery and expansive lawns offer a variety of arts, heritage and nature experiences. Down the hill, you
can trace Singapore's history through stamps at the Singapore Philatelic Museum before stopping for lunch at the
Raffles Hotel. Raffles Hotel was the crown of colonial indulgence with a reputation of luxury. It is at this hotel's bar
where the legendary Singapore Sling was created

} THE QUAYS
ON SINGAPORE
RIVER

Consisting of a trio of Clarke Quay,
Robertson Quay and Boat Quay, you can literally
walk from the mouth of Singapore River through the
river valleys along some of the most pristine walking
paths. Shophouses along Boat Quay that used to
be the centre of trade has now been conserved and
adapted for modern use, offering up various bars,
‘ pubs and restaurants. Warehouses along Clarke
Quay are today Iconic dance clubs and live music
venues, rooftop bars, creating trendy nightspots for heart-pumping entertainment. Together, both Clarke Quay and
Boat Quay is a must-have stop for the city's most lively nightlife spots. As you move further inwards, Robertson Quay
offers a more quiet respite, with locals often seen running along its banks. The area combines upperclass residential
apartments with designer hotels such as M Social and The Warehouse Hotel with wonderful choices of gastronomic
options that would satisfy any foodie.

KAMPONG
GLAM

Some say Kampong Glam really is glam
(a local term meaning ‘glamorous’. The area has
an eclectic blend of history, culture and a super-
trendy lifestyle scene. Start from the landmark Sultan
Mosque, and wander through the many side streets.
The grounds of the former ‘Istana’ (‘palace’) to Sultan
Hussain Mohammed Shah is home to the Malay

history and culture better. Wander the streets and you'll
soon uncover Haji Lane, a row of multi-label stores,
quirky boutiques as well as hip bars and cafes. Or pick

dresses and handmade perfumes from Arab Street and
Bussorah Street. The nasi padang (Indonesian dishes
flavoured with spices and served with rice) at Hjh
Maimunah is famous among locals. Café and boutique

modern grub, and also houses an excellent rooftop

Heritage Centre, where you can get to know Malay cocktail bar.

ROCHER,

CHINATOWN
WALKING TOURS

Operated by The Chinatown Association, there's a
walking tour organised on every day of the week
that let you immerse yourself with the underbelly
of Chinatown. Move your senses with the sights
and sounds of hawkers cooking, coffee brewing
and locals bargain-hunting even as you taste
authentic traditional favourites such as Kopi-O,
water cakes and rice rolls in the "Good Morning,
Ni Hao" walking tour!

Explore the traditional customs that surround the
life of the early Chinese immigrant and discover
the reasons behind each practice in the "Passage
of Life: Birth, Marriage & Death” walking tour.

Visit Chinatown at sundown in the Nightout @
Chinatown Walking Tour, where the streets come
alive! Savour authentic Chinese food and test
your bargaining skills at the Street Market. Take a
leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop
onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.

® chinatown.sg

TRISHAW EXPEDITION
BY TRISHAW UNCLE

Say hello to uncle! Trishaw Uncle pays tribute to all
trishaw riders, for providing transport services rain or
shine, from the time before cars, buses and trains.

Embark on a trishaw expedition that takes you through
the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. Expect

a range of sights such as the Rex Cinema and Sri
Veeramakaliamman Temple and learn more about the
various roads such as Selegie Road and Serangoon
Road. Tours are available for Little India, Kampong
Glam, Chinatown as well the Singapore River.

® trishawuncle.com.sg

singapore_query_034.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are a multi-generational family of 5 (grandparents, parents, children) visiting Singapore for 7 days. They are interested in outdoor adventures, hiking trails, and nature parks, modern art galleries and contemporary culture, cultural heritage sites and traditional architecture. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_034.answer:
Day 1: Start your adventure with a scenic hike at MacRitchie Reservoir Park, exploring the TreeTop Walk and the layers of the rainforest. Afterward, enjoy panoramic views of the city skyline and the Southern Islands at Mount Faber Park, taking in the scenic views and capturing Instagram-worthy pictures.

Day 2: Visit Fort Canning Park to relive the footsteps of Malay kings and British governors, and explore the historical landmarks such as the nine-pound cannon and Fort Gate. In the afternoon, head to East Coast Park for a variety of sporting, entertainment, and dining attractions, including cycling, rollerblading, and water sports.

Day 3: Take a scenic hike in Bukit Timah Hill or explore the jungles of Bukit Timah Nature Reserve by mountain bike or foot. In the evening, enjoy a relaxing walk along the boardwalk of the mangrove swamps in Sungei Buloh Wetland Reserve, observing migratory birds and mud lobsters.

Day 4: Start your day with a relaxing walk along the carved paths of Coney Island. In the afternoon, visit the Punggol Waterway Park by bicycle or explore the options awaiting you on this end of the island. In the evening, enjoy a light meal at a local restaurant and unwind with a relaxing massage at a spa.

Day 5: Take a leisurely walk along the boardwalk of the mangrove swamps in Sungei Buloh Wetland Reserve, observing migratory birds and mud lobsters. In the afternoon, visit the National Gallery Singapore to explore modern art galleries and contemporary culture. In the evening, enjoy a light dinner at a local restaurant and relax with a relaxing massage at a spa.

Day 6: Start your day with a scenic hike at MacRitchie Reservoir Park, exploring the TreeTop Walk and the layers of the rainforest. In the afternoon, visit the National Museum of Singapore to learn about Singapore's cultural heritage and traditional architecture. In the evening, enjoy panoramic views of the city skyline and the Southern Islands at Mount Faber Park, taking in the scenic views and capturing Instagram-worthy pictures.

Day 7: Take a leisurely walk along the boardwalk of the mangrove swamps in Sungei Buloh Wetland Reserve, observing migratory birds and mud lobsters. In the afternoon, visit the National Museum of Singapore to learn about Singapore's cultural heritage and traditional architecture. In the evening, enjoy a light dinner at a local restaurant and relax with a relaxing massage at a spa.

Lighter Day for Recovery: Spend the day relaxing and unwinding at a local spa, enjoying a relaxing massage and a light meal.

contexts.text:
1/10 - SCENIC TRAILS TO RUN OR HIKE IN SINGAPORE /

SCENIC TR

MacRitchie Reservoir Park
Panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of

walking at 25 metres above ground are all part of the
experience when you traverse the TreeTop Walk, a
250-metre-long freestanding suspension bridge. See
first-hand the layers of the rainforest, from the ground
all the way to the canopy and the emergent layer of
trees, when you take on this scenic seven-kilometre-
long roundtrip to the bridge. From the carpark at Venus
Drive, it's a three- to four-hour hike—do note that the
TreeTop Walk only allows access from one direction.

Southern Ridges. Keep your camera on hand when
you hike the photogenic ten-kilometre-long network of
trails known as the Southern Ridges. The route starts
at HarbourFront Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) station and
takes you three to five hours to walk through Mount
Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill and HortPark before
ending at Kent Ridge Park. Soak in the scenic views

of our skyline and the Southern Islands at the peak of
Mount Faber Park, which is also where you can take
photos with the Merlion sculpture—one of seven that
dot the island. For Instagram-worthy pictures, we
definitely recommend Henderson Waves, the highest

pedestrian bridge in Singapore. The post-modern wood

and steel structure's also an ideal venue for a romantic
night stroll, as it's majestically illuminated by glowing
LED lights from 7pm to 7am.

Relive the footsteps of Malay kings and British
governors at Fort Canning Park. This area used to

be home to Malay royalty, and was also where Sir
Stamford Raffles built his first house, which eventually
became the place of residence for governors. Connect
with history when you explore Fort Canning Service
Reservoir to discover landmarks such as the nine-
pound cannon that dates back to the 19th century;
headstones that mark the site of Singapore's first
Christian cemetery; and Fort Gate, a remnant of the
fortress that was built on this hill.

IN SINGAPO

The golden hour washing over the city's CBD is a

sight to behold. Skyscrapers glimmer and Marina

Bay glistens—it all makes for a postcard-perfect
backdrop for your evening run. The area's proximity

to attractions, restaurants and heritage monuments
also means there's plenty to do and see after this

easy 3.9-kilometre route. Start at the Merlion Park
next to One Fullerton and you'll run past The Fullerton
Heritage precinct, across Marina Bay Sands. You can
cut through the underpass that connects the iconic
towers to Gardens by the Bay and whizz pask lakes and
conservatories before entering the Supertree Grove.
End your run with a last dash towards your final stop,
the Marina Barrage where Singapore's skyline lights up
to celebrate the completion of your run goal.

If there's one place in Singapore that's synonymous
with outdoor revelry, it's East Coast Park, where some
seven million locals and tourists flock to for the variety
of sporting, entertainment and dining attractions. Along
this 15-kiliometre stretch of beach, you'll find hordes
of cyclists and roller bladers enjoying the sun and sea
breeze, while cable skiing and water sports are on offer
for those who prefer wetter pursuits.

Sungai Buloh Wetlands Reserve. Enjoy an up-close
look at mud lobsters, tree-climbing crabs and monitor
lizards when you stroll along the 500-metre-long
boardwalk of the mangrove swamps in Sungei Buloh
Wetland Reserve. The boardwalk runs parallel to the
Wetland Centre. Look to the sky when you head to

the Migratory Bird Trail just a short walk away. From
behind the five hides, two platforms and the 18-metre-
tall Aerie Tower featured along the trail, you can

quietly observe migratory birds such as the Common
Redshank and Pacific Golden Plover that shack up in
this reserve from September to March. Kingfishers,
herons and egrets also visit the reserve regularly.

Bukit Timah is an expansive twist of roads and
buildings, but within the district are tranquil spots for
some quiet. Take
a hike up Bukit
Timah Hill or, for
the adventurous,
go off-tangent and
explore the jungles
of Bukit Timah
Nature Reserve by
mountain bike or
foot.

Punggol is a little far off from the city centre, but you'll
be surprised by the options awaiting you on this end
of the island. Explore the Punggol Waterway Park

by bicycle—there are scores of rental shops around
offering hourly rates—or meander the carved paths of
Coney Island.

710 - SCENIC TRAILS TO RUN OR HIKE IN SINGAPORE /

SCENIC TR

MacRitchie Reservoir Park
Panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of

walking at 25 metres above ground are all part of the

of Bukit Timah

Punggol is a little far off from the city centre, but you'll
be surprised by the options awaiting you on this end

from Indonesia who came here to trade with local merchants, has a less pristine past. You could spend days
just soaking in the vibe of this buzzing district. The district is home to museums such as the National Museum
of Singapore, The Singapore Art Museum and Peranakan Museum, and national monuments like the Armenian
Church and Central Fire Station, Singapore's oldest fire station. Explore CHIJMES, an enclave of restaurants and
bars in the middle of the city. The former chapel and school with its green lawns, marble waterfalls, courtyards
and neoclassical buildings — harks back to a bygone, more gracious age. A thriving district with a colourful past,
it now boasts everything shoppers could ever ask for; malls such as Bugis+ and Bugis Junction, charming
boutiques, bustling street markets, and of course, bargains at every corner.

THE COLONIAL
DISTRICT

Singapore's Colonial District is peppered with
reminders of British colonial rule. Together with Bras Basah
Bugis district and adjoining into the Civic District, it's the
centerpiece of Singapore surrounded by more modern
trappings that rise up around it. The district is anchored
by Fort Canning Park, an iconic hilltop landmark that has
witnessed many of Singapore's historical milestones. The
hill once sited the palaces of 14th century Malay Kings and
served as the Headquarters of the Far East Command Centre and British Army Barracks. Today, Fort Canning Park
is a venue for celebrations. Its expansive, sprawling lawns play host to concerts, theatre productions and festivals
such as Shakespeare in the Park, Ballet Under the Stars, and Films at the Fort, while weddings, parties and
gatherings are a regular sight in the park's venue spaces. Its ancient artefacts are a must-see for history buffs, and
its lush greenery and expansive lawns offer a variety of arts, heritage and nature experiences. Down the hill, you
can trace Singapore's history through stamps at the Singapore Philatelic Museum before stopping for lunch at the
Raffles Hotel. Raffles Hotel was the crown of colonial indulgence with a reputation of luxury. It is at this hotel's bar
where the legendary Singapore Sling was created

} THE QUAYS
ON SINGAPORE
RIVER

Consisting of a trio of Clarke Quay,
Robertson Quay and Boat Quay, you can literally
walk from the mouth of Singapore River through the
river valleys along some of the most pristine walking
paths. Shophouses along Boat Quay that used to
be the centre of trade has now been conserved and
adapted for modern use, offering up various bars,
‘ pubs and restaurants. Warehouses along Clarke
Quay are today Iconic dance clubs and live music
venues, rooftop bars, creating trendy nightspots for heart-pumping entertainment. Together, both Clarke Quay and
Boat Quay is a must-have stop for the city's most lively nightlife spots. As you move further inwards, Robertson Quay
offers a more quiet respite, with locals often seen running along its banks. The area combines upperclass residential
apartments with designer hotels such as M Social and The Warehouse Hotel with wonderful choices of gastronomic
options that would satisfy any foodie.

KAMPONG
GLAM

Some say Kampong Glam really is glam
(a local term meaning ‘glamorous’. The area has
an eclectic blend of history, culture and a super-
trendy lifestyle scene. Start from the landmark Sultan
Mosque, and wander through the many side streets.
The grounds of the former ‘Istana’ (‘palace’) to Sultan
Hussain Mohammed Shah is home to the Malay

03 - A QUICK GUIDE TO SINGAPORE’S DISTRICTS /

history and culture better. Wander the streets and you'll
soon uncover Haji Lane, a row of multi-label stores,
quirky boutiques as well as hip bars and cafes. Or pick
up traditional wares such as Persian carpets, kebaya
dresses and handmade perfumes from Arab Street and
Bussorah Street. The nasi padang (Indonesian dishes
flavoured with spices and served with rice) at Hjh
Maimunah is famous among locals. Café and boutique
Maison Ikkoku on Kandahar Street offers tasty
modern grub, and also houses an excellent rooftop

Heritage Centre, where you can get to know Malay cocktail bar.

JALAN BESAR,
ROCHER,
LAVENDER

Now a conserved area, Jalan Besar is home
to an eclectic range of eateries, cafés, entertainment
venues, and religious sites. It's also a hostel hotspot,
and backpackers constantly flock here. Beyond the
neon lights of bars and lounges, Jalan Besar is rife with
hip cafés that are now calling the neighbourhood's
many shophouses home. You can easily spend an
entire afternoon hopping from one spot to another
such as Chye Seng Huat Hardware, all while tucking
into hearty brunch plates, classic French pastries and
modern takes on local cuisine such as Non Entrée
Desserts. The district is also making a name for itself
as a haven for Third Wave coffee, so you will have
plenty of fuel for your trip.

THE CIVIC
DISTRICT

The Civic District is where Singapore's
historical, architectural and cultural heritage started.
Located right at the mouth of the Singapore River, the
Civic District is at the heart of the city's past, with key
landmarks from prominent historical figures such as Sir
Stamford Raffles, the man who founded Singapore, to
up-and-coming architectural icons of the 21st century.
Among key historical landmarks include St Andrew's
Cathedral, National Gallery Singapore which comprises
the historical Supreme Court and City Hall, Padang,
the Asian Civilisations Museum, The Arts House (Old
Parliament House) and Victoria Theatre, overlooking the
magnificent Fullerton Hotel and Esplanade - Theatres
on the Bay which locals affectionately call "the durian”.

BRAS BASAH BUGIS

Bras Basah.Bugis Precinct is where to go for a slice of Singapore's rich heritage, preserved

architecture and palpable energy. Head here for fine museums, national monuments and other

institutions, such as art schools and the Central Public Library. One of Singapore's oldest districts,
Bras Basah derived its name from the Malay term for ‘wet rice’ and Sir Stamford Raffles picked the area to be
the European center of Singapore Town. The adjacent Bugis Street, named after the seafaring Bugis people
from Indonesia who came here to trade with local merchants, has a less pristine past. You could spend days

is a venue for celebrations. Its expansive, sprawling lawns play host to concerts, theatre productions and festivals

where the legendary Singapore Sling was created

‘4 @ letsgobikesingapore.com

CHINATOWN
WALKING TOURS

Operated by The Chinatown Association, there's a
walking tour organised on every day of the week
that let you immerse yourself with the underbelly
of Chinatown. Move your senses with the sights
and sounds of hawkers cooking, coffee brewing
and locals bargain-hunting even as you taste
authentic traditional favourites such as Kopi-O,
water cakes and rice rolls in the "Good Morning,
Ni Hao" walking tour!

Explore the traditional customs that surround the
life of the early Chinese immigrant and discover
the reasons behind each practice in the "Passage
of Life: Birth, Marriage & Death” walking tour.

Visit Chinatown at sundown in the Nightout @
Chinatown Walking Tour, where the streets come
alive! Savour authentic Chinese food and test
your bargaining skills at the Street Market. Take a
leisure Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop
onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River.

® chinatown.sg

TRISHAW EXPEDITION
BY TRISHAW UNCLE

Say hello to uncle! Trishaw Uncle pays tribute to all
trishaw riders, for providing transport services rain or
shine, from the time before cars, buses and trains.

Embark on a trishaw expedition that takes you through
the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. Expect

a range of sights such as the Rex Cinema and Sri
Veeramakaliamman Temple and learn more about the
various roads such as Selegie Road and Serangoon
Road. Tours are available for Little India, Kampong
Glam, Chinatown as well the Singapore River.

® trishawuncle.com.sg

singapore_query_035.client_description: are a couple in their 40s visiting Singapore for 3 days. They are interested in maritime history and waterfront attractions, street food, hawker centers, and cooking experiences, family-friendly attractions and theme parks

singapore_query_036.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 6 university students on a budget visiting Singapore for 4 days. They are interested in botanical gardens and wildlife conservation, luxury experiences and fine dining, photography opportunities and scenic viewpoints, religious sites and spiritual experiences. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_036.answer:
Day 1: Arrival in Singapore
- Check-in at your hotel
- Visit the National Orchid Garden for a beautiful botanical garden experience
- Explore the Botanic Gardens for scenic viewpoints and wildlife conservation
- Enjoy a luxurious lunch at a high-end restaurant
- Attend a photography workshop to capture the city's beauty
- Visit a local temple or spiritual site for a spiritual experience

Day 2: Exploring Singapore's Heritage
- Take a Vespa tour to explore Singapore's heritage lanes and historical landmarks
- Visit the Chinatown Association for a walking tour of the underbelly of Chinatown
- Enjoy a leisurely Trishaw Ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a Bumboat Cruise along Singapore River
- Attend a workshop on Singapore's history and culture
- Visit a local coffee shop for a relaxing break

Day 3: Nature and Wildlife Conservation
- Visit Gardens by the Bay for a unique botanical garden experience
- Explore the Cloud Forest and Flower Dome for a cool-moist and cool-dry climate
- Take a tour with Subaraj Rajathurai to experience the ecosystems he has fought to preserve
- Visit Pulau Ubin for a unique wildlife experience
- Attend a workshop on Singapore's nature reserves and conservation efforts

Day 4: Leisure and Relaxation
- Take a leisurely walk along the Singapore River for scenic viewpoints
- Attend a photography workshop to capture the city's beauty
- Visit a local temple or spiritual site for a spiritual experience
- Enjoy a luxurious lunch at a high-end restaurant
- Attend a workshop on Singapore's history and culture
- Spend the afternoon relaxing and enjoying the city's beauty

Lighter Day for Recovery:
- Take a leisurely walk along the Singapore River for scenic viewpoints
- Attend a photography workshop to capture the city's beauty
- Visit a local temple or spiritual site for a spiritual experience
- Enjoy a leisurely lunch at a local café
- Attend a workshop on Singapore's history and culture
- Spend the afternoon relaxing and enjoying the city's beauty

/ 08 - LITTLE EXPLORERS: BEING WITH MOTHER NATURE /

MEET
SUBARAJ RAJATHURAI

Many of Singapore's nature reserves exist due
" 4 to the efforts of a few individuals like Subaraj
Rajathurai: Self-taught naturalist and veteran

wildlife consultant. Over the last 35 years, he
GARDENS y
BY TH E BAY campaigned peacefully behind the scenes

to preserve some of Singapore's well-loved
ecosystems. In 1987, he and three others drafted
a proposal to save Sungei Buloh, a mangrove

Gardens by the Bay is a quick getaway to some serious greenery, a 101-ha horticultural park with two
conservatories, the Cloud Forest and the Flower Dome. The cool-moist conservatory that is the Cloud Forest
features a 35m-tall mountain covered in plants such as orchids and also sports the world's tallest indoor
waterfall. Meanwhile, the Flower Dome replicates a cool-dry climate and houses plants from the Mediterranean
region and also a Flower Field, where the displays change regularly.

forest in northwest Singapore which was slated
for redevelopment by the government. Thanks
to their perseverance, the wetland was declared
a nature park six years later. In 1992, Subaraj
was also part of the research team responsible
for saving the 123.8 hectares of forest at Lower
Peirce Reservoir.

While tickets are required for entry into the domes, the large three surrounding gardens are open to public to
enjoy. The highlight within the Bay South Garden is the Children's Garden filled with adventure trails for children as
well as the iconic Supertree Grove. The tree-like structures that dominate the Gardens’ landscape that functions
as n environment engine for the gardens and lights up at night with music for a show of its own. Get up close to

the supertrees by exploring the OCBC skyway between the trees —— -
UP y exploring yway / “You can spend five lifetimes exploring nature,

Q 18 Marina Gardens Drive and there would still be more to learn.” says
Subaraj, who fell in love with the rainforest at the
age of 18, during a visit to Bukit Timah Reserve.
Singapore's blend of urban landscapes and
hidden ecosystems keeps him fighting against
rampant urbanisation: “In Singapore, you can
get from a five-star hotel to a rainforest in 20
minutes.”

He believes Singapore is the gateway to Asia, as
much as “it is that gateway for nature."

See Singapore through the eyes of a nature lover:

explorers/subaraj-rajathurai.html

singapore_query_036.client_description: are 6 university students on a budget visiting Singapore for 4 days. singapore_query_037.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 4 history buffs and museum lovers visiting Singapore for 6 days. They are interested in photography opportunities and scenic viewpoints, budget-friendly activities and free attractions. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_037.answer:
Day 1: Arrival and Orientation
- Arrive in Singapore and check into your hotel.
- Visit the Singapore River and take a bumboat cruise to get a sense of the city's history and architecture.
- Explore the Singapore River Walk and visit the Singapore River Museum for a free and educational experience.
- Have a light lunch at a local café or food court.

Day 2: Historical and Cultural Sites
- Visit the Singapore Botanic Gardens for a free and scenic viewpoint.
- Explore the Singapore River and take a bumboat cruise to see historical landmarks and attractions.
- Visit the Singapore River Museum for a free and educational experience.
- Have a light lunch at a local café or food court.

Day 3: Heritage and Art
- Visit the National Museum of Singapore for a free and educational experience.
- Explore the Singapore River and take a bumboat cruise to see historical landmarks and attractions.
- Visit the Singapore River Museum for a free and educational experience.
- Have a light lunch at a local café or food court.

Day 4: Photography and Scenic Views
- Visit the Singapore River and take a bumboat cruise to get a sense of the city's history and architecture.
- Explore the Singapore River Walk and visit the Singapore River Museum for a free and educational experience.
- Have a light lunch at a local café or food court.

Day 5: Lighter Day for Recovery
- Take a leisure trishaw ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a bumboat cruise along Singapore River.
- Visit the Singapore River Museum for a free and educational experience.
- Have a light lunch at a local café or food court.

Day 6: Departure
- Check out of your hotel and depart for home.

Note: This itinerary is designed to provide a mix of history, culture, and scenic views while also including budget-friendly activities and free attractions. The lighter day for recovery is included to allow the clients to rest and recover before their departure.

singapore_query_037.client_description: are 4 history buffs and museum lovers visiting Singapore for 6 days. They are interested in photography opportunities and scenic viewpoints, budget-friendly activities and free attractions

singapore_query_038.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 8 senior travelers (ages 62-72) visiting Singapore for 3 days. They are interested in local markets and authentic cultural experiences, innovative technology and futuristic attractions, street food, hawker centers, and cooking experiences, outdoor adventures, hiking trails, and nature parks. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_038.answer:
Day 1: Explore Singapore's cultural heritage and local markets
- Start the day with a visit to the Singapore River and explore the historic landmarks and museums along the way.
- Take a trishaw ride through the vibrant streets of Singapore and visit the hawker centers and local markets for authentic street food and cultural experiences.
- Visit the Singapore Botanic Gardens for a nature park experience and learn about the city's transformation from a sleepy village to a metropolis.

Day 2: Outdoor adventures and nature parks
- Take a Vespa tour through the heritage lanes of Chinatown and Joo Chiat for a unique perspective on Singapore's history and culture.
- Visit the National Parks Board's various parks and gardens for a nature park experience and learn about the city's transformation from a sleepy village to a metropolis.
- Take a guided walk through the Singapore River and see historical landmarks and museums along the way.

Day 3: Lighter day for recovery
- Take a leisure trishaw ride down to Clarke Quay and hop onto a bumboat cruise along the Singapore River for a relaxing and scenic experience.
- Visit the Singapore River and explore the hawker centers and local markets for authentic street food and cultural experiences.
- Visit the Singapore Botanic Gardens for a nature park experience and learn about the city's transformation from a sleepy village to a metropolis.

Note: This itinerary is designed to provide a mix of cultural experiences, local markets, and nature parks while also including a lighter day for recovery. The itinerary can be adjusted based on the clients' preferences and interests.

singapore_query_040.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are a family of 4 with children aged 4 and 7 visiting Singapore for 5 days. They are interested in traditional crafts and cultural workshops, local markets and authentic cultural experiences, colonial architecture and historical landmarks, luxury experiences and fine dining. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_040.answer:
Day 1: Arrival in Singapore
- Arrive at Changi Airport and check into your hotel
- Light lunch at a local food court
- Visit the National Gallery Singapore for a guided tour and explore the exhibits
- Light dinner at a local restaurant

Day 2: Traditional Crafts and Cultural Workshops
- Visit the Singapore Art Museum for a guided tour and explore the exhibits
- Attend a traditional crafts workshop at the Singapore Art Museum
- Visit the Singapore Botanic Gardens for a guided tour and explore the exhibits
- Light dinner at a local restaurant

Day 3: Local Markets and Authentic Cultural Experiences
- Visit the Singapore River for a guided tour and explore the historical landmarks
- Attend a cultural workshop at the Singapore River
- Visit the Singapore River Market for a guided tour and explore the local markets
- Light dinner at a local restaurant

Day 4: Colonial Architecture and Historical Landmarks
- Visit the Singapore River for a guided tour and explore the historical landmarks
- Attend a colonial architecture tour at the Singapore River
- Visit the Singapore River Market for a guided tour and explore the local markets
- Light dinner at a local restaurant

Day 5: Luxury Experiences and Fine Dining
- Attend a luxury experience tour at the Singapore River
- Visit the Singapore River Market for a guided tour and explore the local markets
- Light dinner at a local restaurant

Lighter Day for Recovery:
- Visit the Singapore River for a guided tour and explore the historical landmarks
- Attend a cultural workshop at the Singapore River
- Visit the Singapore River Market for a guided tour and explore the local markets
- Light dinner at a local restaurant

/ 05 - LITTLE EXPLORERS: SPARKING CREATIVITY /

LITTLE EXPLORERS:
S PA R Kl N G Childhood is a time of natural creativity and curiosity. While in

Singapore, explore some key highlights that gets your child out of

C R EAT IV | TY the comforts of four walls and engage them with a multitude of
sensory experiences that would spark bundles of creative energy.

NATIONAL GALLERY

SINGAPORE is the labour of love

transforming the historical Supreme Court
building and the City Hall into the largest art museum
in Singapore focusing on Southeast Asian art. What
sets it apart is the multitude of kid-friendly exhibits
and installations including the Keppel Centre that
work to instill art appreciation at a young age.
Exhibitions at the the National Gallery changes by
season and is currently showing the Children's
Biennale — until 8 Oct 2017. The first edition of
the Gallery Children's Biennale, a four-month-long KEPPEL CENTRE The newly refreshed Keppel Centre is an exciting space where art
festival organised by the Gallery, invites you to FOR ART inspires new ways of learning. Visitors can enjoy immersive spaces
discover art in a whole new way. Explore dreams EDUCATION AT that encourage imagination, creativity and self-led exploration. The
and stories through site-specific installations, Keppel Centre also provides a lively line-up of programmes for youth,
interactive artworks and a stimulating line-up of NATIONAL GALLERY children and families all year round. This creates opportunities for
music performances, film showcases and art- SINGAPORE parents to bond with their little ones through the arts and stimulates
inspired programmes designed especially for kids young minds in meaningful and enjoyable ways.

singapore_query_040.client_description: are a family of 4 with children aged 4 and 7 visiting Singapore for 5 days. They are interested in traditional crafts and cultural workshops, local markets and authentic cultural experiences, colonial architecture and historical landmarks, luxury experiences and fine dining

singapore_query_041.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 4 university students on a budget visiting Singapore for 7 days. They are interested in local markets and authentic cultural experiences, cultural heritage sites and traditional architecture, ethnic neighborhoods like Chinatown and Little India, modern art galleries and contemporary culture. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_041.answer:
Day 1: Orchard Road - Start your journey in the heart of Singapore's shopping district. Explore the famous shopping malls, restaurants, and entertainment options. Visit the Singapore Visitor Centre for ticketing and reservations, and don't forget to check out the iconic Dempsey Hill neighborhood for a night out.

Day 2: Tiong Bahru - Discover the charming old and new neighborhood with its mix of shophouses, flats, and trendy cafes. Visit the Tiong Bahru Market for a taste of local cuisine and explore the local bookstores and record shops.

Day 3: Little India - Immerse yourself in the vibrant Little India district with its colorful streets, shops, and cultural landmarks. Take a stroll along the streets and back alleys to discover the heritage trail and enjoy the local cuisine.

Day 4: Chinatown - Explore the historic Chinatown district with its traditional customs, authentic food, and cultural landmarks. Take a walking tour to immerse yourself in the underbelly of Chinatown and visit the Nightout @ Chinatown Walking Tour for a night out.

Day 5: National Parks Board - Take a guided walk in the National Parks Board parks and gardens to learn about Singapore's transformation from a sleepy village to the metropolis it is today. Visit Pulau Ubin, Fort Canning Park, and the Botanic Gardens.

Day 6: Trishaw Expedition - Embark on a trishaw expedition that takes you through the vibrant and bustling streets of Singapore. Learn about the various roads such as Selegie Road and Serangoon Road and enjoy the sights along the way.

Day 7: Lighter Day for Recovery - Spend the lighter day relaxing and enjoying the local markets, cultural experiences, and traditional architecture. Visit the Singapore Botanic Gardens for a peaceful stroll and enjoy the local cuisine at a local coffee shop or restaurant.

1/02 - CONTENTS & A QUICK GUIDE TO SINGAPORE'S DISTRICTS /

A QUICK GUIDE

ORCHARD

Don't just sightsee, be an explorer. Orchard

Road, Asia's most famous shopping street, is

home to fashion favourites, specialist stores
and loads of other lifestyle choices. Today, Orchard
Road is flanked by iconic shopping malls, restaurants
and hotels, choc-a-bloc with retail, dining and enter-
tainment choice for every taste and budget.
The Singapore Visitor Centre is located on Orchard
Road just opposite Orchard Gateway. Discover more
places to explore and get help with ticketing and
reservations. Next to the centre is Emerald Hill Road,

lined with bars and clubs to wind down after a long day

of exploration. The east end of Orchard Road leads to
the Bras Basah and Fort Canning Park while the west
end of the street is just a stone's throw away from the
Singapore Botanic Gardens, the city's first and only

UNESCO World Heritage Site and a beautiful garden to

stop by.

Remember to make a detour to Dempsey Hill, one

of Singapore's most hip and quaint neighbourhoods,
nestled away in lush greenery just minutes from
Orchard Road. Here you'll be spoilt for choice for

the night's meal with options that include Michelin-
starred Candlenut, Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar, The
Disgruntled Chef. Or go green and experience Open
Farm Community's refreshing farm-to-table concept.

TIONG BAHRU

Tiong Bahru is the oldest housing estate

in Singapore, and when you visit this.

quaint community, you'll immediately
notice an intriguing mix of old and new. While many
older residents have lived in the shophouses and flats
here for decades, the younger generation flock here
for the food, shops, and culture. And as food goes,
the choices are abundant. From the sprawling Tiong
Bahru Market with its famous chwee kueh to the
hip Tiong Bahru Bakery, there are plenty of options
for a good meal in the morning. Fancy a coffee
and a quick bite? There are lots of cafés to choose
from — Forty Hands, Flock and cupcakes specialists
Plain Vanilla are just a few of them. It's a great place
to go for a spot of retail therapy, too. Independent
bookstore BooksActually stocks plenty of local
titles and retro knick-knacks, while Curated Records
offers a selection of vinyls, from rare vintage LPs to
mainstream hits.

LITTLE INDIA

Singapore's most colourful district, Little

India's bustling streets are a magnet for

explorers. From rows of shops exuding the
aroma of spices, to fortune-telling tables sprawled
along walkways, the precinct has stood as a cultural
vanguard of Singapore. Tucked away in its roads, you'll
find numerous landmarks of the city's many ethnic
and religious groups including the visually stunning
Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple, Kampong Kapor
Methodist Church, and the colourful expressions of
heritage at the House of Tan Teng Niah. Explore Little
India's heritage trail along its streets and back alleys,
and your eyes will be drawn to extravagant murals
showcasing Singapore's colourful past.

When you're done soaking in the sights and sounds,
to Tekka Centre and experience the bustling hawker
and “wet market” on its ground level with a battalion of
rainbow-coloured textile and tailor shops up above.

singapore_query_041.client_description: are 4 university students on a budget visiting Singapore for 7 days. They are interested in local markets and authentic cultural experiences, cultural heritage sites and traditional architecture, ethnic neighborhoods like Chinatown and Little India, modern art galleries and contemporary culture

singapore_query_042.query: You are a personal travel agent. Your clients are 5 university students on a budget visiting Singapore for 3 days. They are interested in innovative technology and futuristic attractions, botanical gardens and wildlife conservation, ethnic neighborhoods like Chinatown and Little India, shopping, entertainment, and nightlife. Please generate an itinerary with one lighter day for recovery.
singapore_query_042.answer:
Day 1: Explore Singapore's cultural and historical landmarks, including the Singapore River, Fort Canning Park, and the Botanic Gardens. Take a trishaw expedition to get a unique perspective on the city's streets and history.

Day 2: Visit the National Parks Board's Central Nature Reserve and learn about Singapore's transformation from a sleepy village to a metropolis. Take a guided walk through the various parks and gardens, and enjoy local drinks and snacks at a 'coffeeshop'.

Day 3: Explore the ethnic neighborhoods of Chinatown and Little India, including the "Good Morning, Ni Hao" walking tour and the "Passage of Life: Birth, Marriage & Death" walking tour. Visit the Singapore River and take a leisure Trishaw Ride.

Day 4: Take a Vespa tour through the heritage lanes of Chinatown and Joo Chiat, or go on a food and pub trail. Visit the Singapore River and enjoy a Bumboat Cruise.

Day 5: Lighten up with a lighter day for recovery. Visit the Singapore River and take a leisure Trishaw Ride, or explore the Singapore River by boat. Enjoy local drinks and snacks at a 'coffeeshop' and try your bargaining skills at the Street Market.

contexts.text:
1/10 - SCENIC TRAILS TO RUN OR HIKE IN SINGAPORE /

SCENIC TR

MacRitchie Reservoir Park
Panoramic views of the forest and the thrill of

walking at 25 metres above ground are all part of the
experience when you traverse the TreeTop Walk, a
250-metre-long freestanding suspension bridge. See
first-hand the layers of the rainforest, from the ground
all the way to the canopy and the emergent layer of
trees, when you take on this scenic seven-kilometre-
long roundtrip to the bridge. From the carpark at Venus
Drive, it's a three- to four-hour hike—do note that the
TreeTop Walk only allows access from one direction.

Southern Ridges. Keep your camera on hand when
you hike the photogenic ten-kilometre-long network of
trails known as the Southern Ridges. The route starts
at HarbourFront Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) station and
takes you three to five hours to walk through Mount
Faber Park, Telok Blangah Hill and HortPark before
ending at Kent Ridge Park. Soak in the scenic views

of our skyline and the Southern Islands at the peak of
Mount Faber Park, which is also where you can take
photos with the Merlion sculpture—one of seven that
dot the island. For Instagram-worthy pictures, we
definitely recommend Henderson Waves, the highest

pedestrian bridge in Singapore. The post-modern wood

and steel structure's also an ideal venue for a romantic
night stroll, as it's majestically illuminated by glowing
LED lights from 7pm to 7am.

Relive the footsteps of Malay kings and British
governors at Fort Canning Park. This area used to

be home to Malay royalty, and was also where Sir
Stamford Raffles built his first house, which eventually
became the place of residence for governors. Connect
with history when you explore Fort Canning Service
Reservoir to discover landmarks such as the nine-
pound cannon that dates back to the 19th century;
headstones that mark the site of Singapore's first
Christian cemetery; and Fort Gate, a remnant of the
fortress that was built on this hill.

IN SINGAPO

The golden hour washing over the city's CBD is a

sight to behold. Skyscrapers glimmer and Marina

Bay glistens—it all makes for a postcard-perfect
backdrop for your evening run. The area's proximity

to attractions, restaurants and heritage monuments
also means there's plenty to do and see after this

easy 3.9-kilometre route. Start at the Merlion Park
next to One Fullerton and you'll run past The Fullerton
Heritage precinct, across Marina Bay Sands. You can
cut through the underpass that connects the iconic
towers to Gardens by the Bay and whizz pask lakes and
conservatories before entering the Supertree Grove.
End your run with a last dash towards your final stop,
the Marina Barrage where Singapore's skyline lights up
to celebrate the completion of your run goal.

If there's one place in Singapore that's synonymous
with outdoor revelry, it's East Coast Park, where some
seven million locals and tourists flock to for the variety
of sporting, entertainment and dining attractions. Along
this 15-kiliometre stretch of beach, you'll find hordes
of cyclists and roller bladers enjoying the sun and sea
breeze, while cable skiing and water sports are on offer
for those who prefer wetter pursuits.

Sungai Buloh Wetlands Reserve. Enjoy an up-close
look at mud lobsters, tree-climbing crabs and monitor
lizards when you stroll along the 500-metre-long
boardwalk of the mangrove swamps in Sungei Buloh
Wetland Reserve. The boardwalk runs parallel to the
Wetland Centre. Look to the sky when you head to

the Migratory Bird Trail just a short walk away. From
behind the five hides, two platforms and the 18-metre-
tall Aerie Tower featured along the trail, you can

quietly observe migratory birds such as the Common
Redshank and Pacific Golden Plover that shack up in
this reserve from September to March. Kingfishers,
herons and egrets also visit the reserve regularly.

Bukit Timah is an expansive twist of roads and
buildings, but within the district are tranquil spots for
some quiet. Take
a hike up Bukit
Timah Hill or, for
the adventurous,
go off-tangent and
explore the jungles
of Bukit Timah
Nature Reserve by
mountain bike or
foot.

Punggol is a little far off from the city centre, but you'll
be surprised by the options awaiting you on this end
of the island. Explore the Punggol Waterway Park

by bicycle—there are scores of rental shops around
offering hourly rates—or meander the carved paths of
Coney Island.

singapore_query_043.client_description: are a family of 4 with children aged 5, 9, and 13 visiting Singapore for 3 days.
